[You]74-mr. germaine are in a state of delusion ; [I]0-i shall speak to [the doctor]364-the doctor . ” “[364-the doctor] By all means , [[my]0-i dear mother]807-my dear mother . [Mr. MacGlue]104-mr. macglue is [a sensible person]808-a sensible person . [We]809-we pass [[his]104-mr. macglue house]164-his house on [our]809-we way [home]2233-home , and [we]809-we will ask [him]104-mr. macglue to dinner . In the meantime , let [us]809-we say no more on the subject till [we]809-we see [the doctor]364-the doctor . ” [I]364-the doctor spoke lightly , but [I]364-the doctor really meant what [I]364-the doctor said . [My]364-the doctor mind was sadly disturbed ; [my]364-the doctor nerves were so shaken that the slightest noises on [the road]2726-the road startled [me]364-the doctor . The opinion of [a man like [Mr. MacGlue]104-mr. macglue]2924-a man like mr. macglue [, who looked at all mortal matters from the same immovably practical point of view]2925-, who looked at all mortal matters from the same immovably practical point of view , might really have its use , in [my]364-the doctor case , as a species of moral remedy . [We]809-we waited until the dessert was on the table , and [the servants]2926-the servants had left [the dining - room]217-the dining - room . Then [I]364-the doctor told [my]364-the doctor story to [the Scotch doctor]2928-the scotch doctor as [I]364-the doctor have told it [here]586-here ; and , that done , [I]364-the doctor opened the sketch - book to let [him]2928-the scotch doctor see the writing for [himself]2928-the scotch doctor . Had [I]364-the doctor turned to the wrong page ? [I]364-the doctor started to [my]364-the doctor feet , and held the book close to the light of the lamp that hung over the dining table . No : [I]364-the doctor had found the right page . There was [my]364-the doctor half - finished drawing of the waterfall — but where were the two lines of writing beneath ? Gone ! [I]364-the doctor strained [my]364-the doctor eyes ; [I]364-the doctor looked and looked . And the blank white paper looked back at [me]364-the doctor . [I]364-the doctor placed the open leaf before [[my]364-the doctor mother]365-my mother . “[364-the doctor] [You]813-you saw it as plainly as [I]0-i did , ” [I]813-you said . “[813-you] Are [my]0-i own eyes deceiving [me]0-i ? [He]364-the doctor took [me]0-i completely by surprise . No incredulous smile appeared on [his]364-the doctor face ; no jesting words passed [his]364-the doctor lips . [He]364-the doctor was listening to [us]2933-us attentively . [I]0-i declare that [I]0-i took the book in [my]0-i hand , and saw these words written in it , ‘ When the full moon shines on [Saint Anthony]105-saint anthony ’s Well . ’ Not more than three hours have passed since that time ; and , see for [yourself]813-you , not a vestige of the writing remains . ” “[813-you] Not a vestige of the writing remains , ” [Mr. MacGlue]104-mr. macglue repeated , quietly . “[813-you] If [you]813-you feel the slightest doubt of what [I]0-i have told [you]813-you , ” [I]365-my mother went on , “[365-my mother] ask [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother ; [she]365-my mother will bear witness that [she]365-my mother saw the writing too . ” “[365-my mother] [I]0-i do n’t doubt that [you]813-you both saw the writing , ” answered [Mr. MacGlue]104-mr. macglue , with a composure that surprised [me]813-you . “[813-you] Can [you]813-you account for it ? ” [I]813-you asked . “[813-you] Well , ” said [the impenetrable doctor]2934-the impenetrable doctor , “[813-you] if [I]0-i set [my]0-i wits at work , [I]0-i believe [I]0-i might account for it to the satisfaction of [some people]816-some people . [I]0-i mean no offense , [Mr. Germaine]74-mr. germaine — ” “[74-mr. germaine] [I]0-i take no offense , [doctor]674-doctor . [I]0-i do n’t believe in the rational explanation [myself]0-i . ” This was surprising , to say the least of it . “[0-i] What do [you]0-i believe in ? ” [I]0-i inquired . [Mr. MacGlue]104-mr. macglue declined to let [me]0-i hurry [him]104-mr. macglue . “[0-i] Wait a little , ” [he]104-mr. macglue said . “[0-i] There ’s the irrational explanation to try next . Maybe it will fit itself to the present state of [your]813-you mind better than the other . [We]820-we will say this time that [you]813-you have really seen the ghost ( or double ) of [a living person]821-a living person . Very good . If [you]813-you can suppose [a disembodied spirit]822-a disembodied spirit to appear in earthly clothing — of silk or merino , as the case may be — it ’s no great stretch to suppose , next , that [this same spirit]823-this same spirit is capable of holding a mortal pencil , and of writing mortal words in a mortal sketching - book . And if the ghost vanishes ( which [your]813-you ghost did ) , it seems supernaturally appropriate that the writing should follow the example and vanish too . And the reason of the vanishment may be ( if [you]813-you want a reason ) , either that [the ghost]824-the ghost does not like letting [a stranger like [me]0-i]825-a stranger like me into [its]824-the ghost secrets , or that vanishing is a settled habit of ghosts and of everything associated with [them]824-the ghost , or that this ghost has changed [its]824-the ghost mind in the course of three hours ( being the ghost of [a woman]237-a woman , [I]0-i am sure that ’s not wonderful ) , and does n’t care to see [you]813-you ‘ when the full moon shines on [Saint Anthony]105-saint anthony ’s Well . ’ There ’s the irrational explanation for [you]813-you . And , speaking for [myself]0-i , [I]0-i ’m bound to add that [I]0-i do n’t set a pin ’s value on that explanation either . ” [Mr. MacGlue]104-mr. macglue ’s sublime indifference to both sides of the question began to irritate [me]0-i . “[0-i] In plain words , [doctor]674-doctor , ” [I]0-i said , “[0-i] [you]674-doctor do n’t think the circumstances that [I]0-i have mentioned to [you]674-doctor worthy of serious investigation ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t think serious investigation capable of dealing with the circumstances , ” answered [the doctor]364-the doctor . “[0-i] Put it in that way , and [you]813-you put it right . Not long after [I]954-i had come to [myself]954-i [I]954-i heard a church clock strike the hour . Reckoning from one time to the other , it must have been quite three hours from the time when [I]954-i first lay down to the time when [I]954-i got up again . ”[954-i] Was the clew to the mysterious disappearance of the writing to be found here ? Looking back by the light of later discoveries , [I]0-i am inclined to think that it was . In three hours the lines traced by the apparition of [her]954-i had vanished . In three hours [she]954-i had come to [herself]954-i , and had felt ashamed of the familiar manner in which [she]954-i had communicated with [me]0-i in [her]954-i sleeping state . While [she]954-i had trusted [me]0-i in the trance — trusted [me]0-i because [her]954-i spirit was then free to recognize [my]0-i spirit — the writing had remained on the page . When [her]954-i waking will counteracted the influence of [her]954-i sleeping will , the writing disappeared . Is this the explanation ? If it is not , where is the explanation to be found ? [I]0-i read and reread [her]1015-her letter , on the chance that some slip of the pen might furnish the clew which [I]0-i had failed to find in any other way . Here is the narrative that [she]1015-her addressed to [me]0-i , copied from the original , word for word : “ [DEAR SIR]3048-dear sir — Forgive [me]1015-her for leaving [you]3048-dear sir again as [I]1015-her left [you]3048-dear sir in [Perthshire]12-perthshire . [I]0-i said to [myself]0-i , quite calmly , as [I]0-i went along , ‘ There is the end of it , and the sooner the better . ’ “[0-i] What happened after that , [you]2230-sir know as well as [I]0-i do . [I]0-i may get on to the next morning — the morning when [I]0-i so ungratefully left [you]2230-sir at [the inn]2784-the inn by [the river - side]2790-the river - side . “ [I]0-i had but one reason , [sir]2230-sir , for going away by the first conveyance that [I]0-i could find to take [me]0-i , and this was the fear that [Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt might discover [me]0-i if [I]0-i remained in [Perthshire]12-perthshire . [He]2230-sir declared that [he]2230-sir had been entrapped into a private marriage with [a profligate woman]3061-a profligate woman when [he]2230-sir was little more than [a lad]3062-a lad . VAN BRANDT]113-m. van brandt . “[1078-your grateful servant] P.S.—I sign [my]0-i own name ( or the name which [I]0-i once thought was [mine]0-i ) as a proof that [I]0-i have honestly written the truth about [myself]0-i , from first to last . [I]2230-sir read it in the temper of [a thoroughly disappointed and thoroughly unreasonable man]3084-a thoroughly disappointed and thoroughly unreasonable man . Whatever poor [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt had done , [she]103-mrs. van brandt had done wrong . It was wrong of [her]103-mrs. van brandt , in the first place , to have married at all . It was wrong of [her]103-mrs. van brandt to contemplate receiving [Mr. Van Brandt]102-mr. van brandt again , even if [[his]102-mr. van brandt lawful wife]3085-his lawful wife had died in the interval . It was wrong of [her]103-mrs. van brandt to return [my]2230-sir letter of introduction , after [I]2230-sir had given [myself]2230-sir the trouble of altering it to suit [her]103-mrs. van brandt capricious fancy . It was wrong of [her]103-mrs. van brandt to take an absurdly prudish view of a stolen kiss and a tender declaration , and to fly from [me]2230-sir as if [I]2230-sir were as great a scoundrel as [Mr. Van Brandt]102-mr. van brandt [himself]102-mr. van brandt . And last , and more than all , it was wrong of [her]103-mrs. van brandt to sign [her]103-mrs. van brandt Christian name in initial only . Van Brandt]113-m. van brandt ! ” [I]85-mary might call [her]103-mrs. van brandt [Maria]114-maria , [Margaret]115-margaret , [Martha]116-martha , [Mabel]117-mabel , [Magdalen]118-magdalen , [Mary]85-mary — no , not [Mary]85-mary . [The old boyish love]3087-the old boyish love was dead and gone , but [I]85-mary owed some respect to the memory of it . Why degrade [myself]85-mary by trying to puzzle out a means of tracing [her]85-mary in [her]85-mary letter ? In the flower of [my]85-mary age , with a handsome fortune , with [the world]287-the world before [me]85-mary , full of [interesting female faces and charming female figures]3093-interesting female faces and charming female figures , what course did it become [me]85-mary to take ? To go back to [[my]85-mary country - house]2684-my country - house , and mope over the loss of [a woman who had deliberately deserted [me]85-mary]3095-a woman who had deliberately deserted me ? or to send for [a courier]3096-a courier and [a traveling carriage]3097-a traveling carriage , and forget [her]85-mary gayly among [foreign people]3098-foreign people and foreign scenes ? In the state of [my]85-mary temper at that moment , the idea of a pleasure tour in [Europe]4-europe fired [my]85-mary imagination . [I]85-mary first astonished [the people at [the hotel]156-the hotel]3099-the people at the hotel by ordering all further inquiries after [the missing Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt to be stopped ; and then [I]85-mary opened [my]85-mary writing desk and wrote to tell [[my]85-mary mother]365-my mother frankly and fully of [my]85-mary new plans . The answer arrived by return of post . To [my]85-mary surprise and delight , [[my]85-mary good mother]2400-my good mother was not satisfied with only formally approving of [my]85-mary new resolution . With an energy which [I]85-mary had not ventured to expect from [her]2400-my good mother , [she]2400-my good mother had made all [her]2400-my good mother arrangements for leaving [home]2233-home , and had started for [Edinburgh]18-edinburgh to join [me]85-mary as [[my]85-mary traveling companion]3104-my traveling companion . “[85-mary] [You]1082-you shall not go away alone , [George]74-mr. germaine , ” [she]2400-my good mother wrote , “[74-mr. germaine] while [I]0-i have strength and spirits to keep [you]1082-you company . ” In three days from the time when [I]0-i read those words [our]3105-we preparations were completed , and [we]3105-we were on [our]3105-we way to [the Continent]29-the continent . [WE]3105-we visited [France]30-france , [Germany]31-germany , and [Italy]32-italy ; and [we]3105-we were absent from [England]1-england nearly two years . Had time and change justified [my]0-i confidence in [them]3106-them ? Was the image of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt an image long since dismissed from [my]0-i mind ? No ! Do what [I]0-i might , [I]0-i was still ( in the prophetic language of [Dame Dermody]88-dame dermody ) taking the way to reunion with [my]0-i kindred spirit in the time to come . For the first two or three months of [our]3105-we travels [I]0-i was haunted by dreams of [the woman who had so resolutely left [me]0-i]3107-the woman who had so resolutely left me . Seeing [her]3107-the woman who had so resolutely left me in [my]0-i sleep , always graceful , always charming , always modestly tender toward [me]0-i , [I]0-i waited in the ardent hope of again beholding the apparition of [her]3107-the woman who had so resolutely left me in [my]0-i waking hours — of again being summoned to meet [her]3107-the woman who had so resolutely left me at a given place and time . [My]0-i anticipations were not fulfilled ; no apparition showed itself . The dreams themselves grew less frequent and less vivid and then ceased altogether . Was this a sign that the days of [her]3107-the woman who had so resolutely left me adversity were at an end ? Having no further need of help , had [she]3107-the woman who had so resolutely left me no further remembrance of [the man who had tried to help [her]3107-the woman who had so resolutely left me]3108-the man who had tried to help her ? Were [we]3105-we never to meet again ? [I]0-i said to [myself]0-i : “[0-i] [I]0-i am unworthy of the name of [man]178-man if [I]0-i do n’t forget [her]1084-her now ! ” [She]3107-the woman who had so resolutely left me still kept [her]3107-the woman who had so resolutely left me place in [my]74-mr. germaine memory , say what [I]74-mr. germaine might . [I]74-mr. germaine saw all the wonders of Nature and Art which [foreign countries]3109-foreign countries could show [me]74-mr. germaine . [I]74-mr. germaine lived in the dazzling light of the best society that [Paris]33-paris , [Rome]34-rome , [Vienna]35-vienna could assemble . [I]74-mr. germaine passed hours on hours in the company of [the most accomplished and most beautiful women whom [Europe]4-europe]3110-the most accomplished and most beautiful women whom europe could produce — and still that solitary figure at [Saint Anthony]105-saint anthony ’s Well , those grand gray eyes that had rested on [me]74-mr. germaine so sadly at parting , held their place in [my]74-mr. germaine memory , stamped their image on [my]74-mr. germaine heart . Whether [I]74-mr. germaine resisted [my]74-mr. germaine infatuation , or whether [I]74-mr. germaine submitted to it , [I]74-mr. germaine still longed for [her]3111-her . [I]74-mr. germaine did all [I]74-mr. germaine could to conceal the state of [my]74-mr. germaine mind from [[my]74-mr. germaine mother]365-my mother . But [her]3111-her loving eyes discovered the secret : [she]3111-her saw that [I]74-mr. germaine suffered , and suffered with [me]74-mr. germaine . More than once [she]3111-her said : “[74-mr. germaine] [George]74-mr. germaine , the good end is not to be gained by traveling ; let [us]1085-us go [home]2233-home . ” More than once [I]74-mr. germaine answered , with the bitter and obstinate resolution of despair : “[74-mr. germaine] No . Let [us]1085-us try [more new people]1087-more new people and more new scenes . ” It was only when [I]1087-more new people found [her]3111-her health and strength beginning to fail under the stress of continual traveling that [I]1087-more new people consented to abandon the hopeless search after oblivion , and to turn homeward at last . [[My]1087-more new people mother]365-my mother now represented the one interest that held [me]1087-more new people nobly and endearingly to life . [I]74-mr. germaine had discovered [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt ! [She]103-mrs. van brandt sat in front — but not alone . [I]1099-i went to [[my]1099-i club]3191-my club , and joined [a convivial party]3192-a convivial party at a supper table , and poured glass after glass of champagne down [my]1099-i throat , without feeling the slightest sense of exhilaration , without losing for an instant the consciousness of [my]1099-i own contemptible conduct . How bitterly [you]74-mr. germaine have disappointed [me]0-i ! ” [Her]0-i reproaches passed by [me]74-mr. germaine unheeded . They only heightened [her]0-i color ; they only added a new rapture to the luxury of looking at [her]0-i . “[74-mr. germaine] If [you]74-mr. germaine loved [me]0-i as faithfully as [I]0-i love [you]74-mr. germaine , ” [I]74-mr. germaine said , “[74-mr. germaine] [you]74-mr. germaine would understand why [I]0-i am [here]586-here . Before [I]0-i could speak again , [she]0-i suddenly faced [me]0-i , and struck [her]0-i open hand on the table with a passionate resolution which [I]0-i now saw in [her]0-i for the first time . “[0-i] Stop ! ” [she]0-i cried . “[0-i] There must be an end to this . And an end there shall be . Do [you]1112-your know who [that man]572-that man is who has just left [the house]258-the house ? Answer [me]0-i , [Mr. Germaine]74-mr. germaine ! [I]0-i am speaking in earnest . ” There was no choice but to answer [her]0-i . [She]0-i was indeed in earnest — vehemently in earnest . “[0-i] [His]572-that man letter tells [me]0-i , ” [I]572-that man said , “[572-that man] that [he]572-that man is [Mr. Van Brandt]102-mr. van brandt . ” [She]0-i sat down again , and turned [her]0-i face away from [me]572-that man . “[572-that man] Do [you]0-i know how [he]572-that man came to write to [you]0-i ? ” [she]0-i asked . “[572-that man] Do [you]0-i know what made [him]572-that man invite [you]0-i to [this house]569-this house ? ” [I]572-that man thought of the suspicion that had crossed [my]572-that man mind when [I]572-that man read [Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt ’s letter . [I]0-i kept [my]0-i situation for three months , and then [I]0-i was obliged to leave it . ’ ” [[My]1162-my aunt mother]365-my mother paused . [I]1162-my aunt thought directly of the strange postscript which [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt had made [me]1162-my aunt add to the letter that [I]1162-my aunt wrote for [her]1162-my aunt at [the Edinburgh inn]3234-the edinburgh inn . In that case also [she]1162-my aunt had only contemplated remaining in [her]1162-my aunt employment for three months ’ time . “[1162-my aunt] Why was [she]1162-my aunt obliged to leave [her]1162-my aunt situation ? ” [I]1162-my aunt asked . “[1162-my aunt] [I]0-i put that question to [her]1162-my aunt [myself]0-i , ” replied [[my]1162-my aunt mother]365-my mother . “[1162-my aunt] [She]1162-my aunt made no direct reply — [she]1162-my aunt changed color , and looked confused . ‘ [I]0-i will tell [you]0-i afterward , [madam]2256-madam , ’ [she]1162-my aunt said . ‘ Please let [me]0-i go on now . [[My]0-i aunt]1162-my aunt was angry with [me]0-i for leaving [my]0-i employment — and [she]1162-my aunt was more angry still , when [I]0-i told [her]1162-my aunt the reason . [She]1162-my aunt said [I]0-i had failed in duty toward [her]1162-my aunt in not speaking frankly at first . [We]1168-we parted coolly . [I]0-i had saved a little money from [my]0-i wages ; and [I]0-i did well enough while [my]0-i savings lasted . When they came to an end , [I]0-i tried to get employment again , and [I]0-i failed . [[My]0-i aunt]1162-my aunt said , and said truly , that [[her]1162-my aunt husband]206-her husband ’s income was barely enough to support [[his]206-her husband family]1171-his family : [she]1162-my aunt could do nothing for [me]0-i , and [I]0-i could do nothing for [myself]0-i . [I]0-i wrote to [[my]0-i aunt]1162-my aunt at [Glasgow]14-glasgow , and received no answer . [Starvation]119-starvation stared [me]0-i in the face , when [I]0-i saw in a newspaper an advertisement addressed to [me]0-i by [Mr. Van Brandt]102-mr. van brandt . [He]102-mr. van brandt implored [me]0-i to write to [him]102-mr. van brandt ; [he]102-mr. van brandt declared that [his]102-mr. van brandt life without [me]0-i was too desolate to be endured ; [he]102-mr. van brandt solemnly promised that there should be no interruption to [my]0-i tranquillity if [I]0-i would return to [him]102-mr. van brandt . If [I]0-i had only had [myself]0-i to think of , [I]0-i would have begged [my]0-i bread in [the streets]929-the streets rather than return to [him]102-mr. van brandt — ‘ ” [I]1175-she interrupted the narrative at that point . “[1175-she] What [other person]1174-other person could [she]1175-she have had to think of ? ” [I]1175-she said . “[1175-she] Is it possible , [George]74-mr. germaine , ” [[my]1175-she mother]365-my mother rejoined , “[1175-she] that [you]74-mr. germaine have no suspicion of what [she]1175-she was alluding to when [she]1175-she said those words ? ” The question passed by [me]1175-she unheeded : [my]1175-she thoughts were dwelling bitterly on [Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt and [his]102-mr. van brandt advertisement . “[1175-she] [She]1175-she answered the advertisement , of course ? ” [I]1175-she said . “[1175-she] And [she]1175-she saw [Mr. Van Brandt]102-mr. van brandt , ” [[my]1175-she mother]365-my mother went on . “[1175-she] [She]1175-she gave [me]0-i no detailed account of the interview between [them]1176-them . ‘ [He]102-mr. van brandt reminded [me]0-i , ’ [she]0-i said , ‘ of what [I]0-i knew to be true — that [the woman who had entrapped [him]102-mr. van brandt into marrying [her]1175-she]1177-the woman who had entrapped him into marrying her was [an incurable drunkard]1178-an incurable drunkard , and that [his]102-mr. van brandt ever living with [her]1175-she again was out of the question . Still [she]1175-she was alive , and [she]1175-she had a right to the name at least of [[his]102-mr. van brandt wife]215-his wife . [I]0-i wo n’t attempt to excuse [my]0-i returning to [him]102-mr. van brandt , knowing the circumstances as [I]0-i did . [I]0-i will only say that [I]0-i could see no other choice before [me]0-i , in [my]0-i position at the time . It is needless to trouble [you]1180-you with what [I]0-i have suffered since , or to speak of what [I]0-i may suffer still . [I]0-i am [a lost woman]1181-a lost woman . Be under no alarm , [madam]2256-madam , about [[your]1180-you son]2257-your son . [I]0-i shall remember proudly to the end of [my]0-i life that [he]102-mr. van brandt once offered [me]0-i the honor and the happiness of becoming [[his]102-mr. van brandt wife]215-his wife ; but [I]0-i know what is due to [him]102-mr. van brandt and to [you]1180-you . [I]0-i have seen [him]102-mr. van brandt for the last time . The one thing that remains to be done is to satisfy [him]102-mr. van brandt that [our]1185-our marriage is impossible . [You]1180-you are [a mother]1138-a mother ; [you]1180-you will understand why [I]0-i reveal the obstacle which stands between [us]1185-our — not to [him]102-mr. van brandt , but to [you]1180-you . ’ [She]0-i rose saying those words , and opened the folding - doors which led from [the parlor]2380-the parlor into [a back room]1188-a back room . After an absence of a few moments only , [she]0-i returned . ” At that crowning point in the narrative , [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother stopped . Was [she]365-my mother afraid to go on ? or did [she]365-my mother think it needless to say more ? “[0-i] Well ? ” [I]0-i said . “[0-i] Must [I]0-i really tell it to [you]1180-you in words , [George]74-mr. germaine ? Ca n’t [you]1180-you guess how it ended , even yet ? ” There were two difficulties in the way of [my]1180-you understanding [her]0-i . [I]1180-you had [a man]2326-a man ’s bluntness of perception , and [I]1180-you was half maddened by suspense . Incredible as it may appear , [I]1180-you was too dull to guess the truth even now . “[1180-you] When [she]0-i returned to [me]0-i , ” [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother resumed , “[0-i] [she]0-i was not alone . [She]0-i had with [her]0-i [a lovely little girl , just old enough to walk with the help of [[her]1189-a lovely little girl , just old enough to walk with the help of her mother ’s hand mother]1190-her mother ’s hand]1189-a lovely little girl , just old enough to walk with the help of her mother ’s hand . [She]0-i tenderly kissed [the child]2711-the child , and then [she]0-i put it on [my]0-i lap . ‘ There is [my]0-i only comfort , ’ [she]0-i said , simply ; ‘ and there is the obstacle to [my]0-i ever becoming [[Mr. Germaine]74-mr. germaine ’s wife]232-mr. germaine ’s wife . ’ ” [[Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt ’s child]3241-van brandt ’s child ! [[Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt ’s child]3241-van brandt ’s child ! The postscript which [she]0-i had made [me]0-i add to [my]0-i letter ; the incomprehensible withdrawal from the employment in which [she]0-i was prospering ; the disheartening difficulties which had brought [her]0-i to the brink of starvation ; the degrading return to [the man who had cruelly deceived [her]0-i]3243-the man who had cruelly deceived her — all was explained , all was excused now ! With [an infant at the breast]3244-an infant at the breast , how could [she]0-i obtain a new employment ? With famine staring [her]0-i in the face , what else could [the friendless woman]3245-the friendless woman do but return to [the father of [[her]0-i child]3247-her child]3246-the father of her child ? What claim had [I]0-i on [her]0-i , by comparison with [him]3243-the man who had cruelly deceived her ? What did it matter , now that [the poor creature]273-the poor creature secretly returned the love that [I]0-i felt for [her]0-i ? There was [the child]2711-the child , an obstacle between [us]3250-us — there was [his]3243-the man who had cruelly deceived her hold on [her]0-i , now that [he]3243-the man who had cruelly deceived her had got [her]0-i back ! What was [my]0-i hold worth ? All social proprieties and all social laws answered the question : Nothing ! [My]0-i head sunk on [my]0-i breast ; [I]0-i received the blow in silence . [[My]0-i good mother]2400-my good mother took [my]0-i hand . “[0-i] [You]1193-you understand it now , [George]74-mr. germaine ? ” [she]2400-my good mother said , sorrowfully . “[805-mother] Yes , [mother]805-mother ; [I]0-i understand it . ” “[805-mother] There was one thing [she]1195-she wished [me]0-i to say to [you]74-mr. germaine , [[my]0-i dear]657-my dear , which [I]0-i have not mentioned yet . [She]1195-she entreats [you]74-mr. germaine not to suppose that [she]1195-she had the faintest idea of [her]1195-she situation when [she]1195-she attempted to destroy [herself]1195-she . [Her]1195-she first suspicion that it was possible [she]1195-she might become [a mother]1138-a mother was conveyed to [her]1195-she at [Edinburgh]18-edinburgh , in a conversation with [[her]1195-she aunt]1198-her aunt . It is impossible , [George]74-mr. germaine , not to feel compassionately toward [this poor woman]1199-this poor woman . Regrettable as [her]1195-she position is , [I]0-i can not see that [she]1195-she is to blame for it . [She]1195-she was [the innocent victim of a vile fraud]1200-the innocent victim of a vile fraud when [that man]572-that man married [her]1195-she ; [she]1195-she has suffered undeservedly since ; and [she]1195-she has behaved nobly to [you]74-mr. germaine and to [me]0-i . [I]0-i only do [her]1195-she justice in saying that [she]1195-she is [a woman in a thousand]1202-a woman in a thousand — [a woman worthy , under happier circumstances]1203-a woman worthy , under happier circumstances , to be [[my]0-i daughter]1204-my daughter and [[your]74-mr. germaine wife]2205-your wife . [I]0-i feel for [you]74-mr. germaine , and feel with [you]74-mr. germaine , [[my]0-i dear]657-my dear — [I]0-i do , with [my]0-i whole heart . ” So this scene in [my]74-mr. germaine life was , to all appearance , a scene closed forever . As it had been with [my]74-mr. germaine love , in the days of [[my]74-mr. germaine boyhood]279-my boyhood , so it was again now with the love of [my]74-mr. germaine riper age ! Later in the day , when [I]74-mr. germaine had in some degree recovered [my]74-mr. germaine self - possession , [I]74-mr. germaine wrote to [Mr. Van Brandt]102-mr. van brandt — as [she]3253-she had foreseen [I]74-mr. germaine should write!—to apologize for breaking [my]74-mr. germaine engagement to dine with [him]102-mr. van brandt . Could [I]74-mr. germaine trust to a letter also , to say the farewell words for [me]74-mr. germaine to [the woman whom [I]74-mr. germaine had loved and lost]3254-the woman whom i had loved and lost ? No ! It was better for [her]3254-the woman whom i had loved and lost , and better for [me]74-mr. germaine , that [I]74-mr. germaine should not write . And yet the idea of leaving [her]3254-the woman whom i had loved and lost in silence was more than [my]74-mr. germaine fortitude could endure . [Her]3254-the woman whom i had loved and lost last words at parting ( as they were repeated to [me]74-mr. germaine by [[my]74-mr. germaine mother]365-my mother ) had expressed the hope that [I]74-mr. germaine should not think hardly of [her]3254-the woman whom i had loved and lost in the future . How could [I]74-mr. germaine assure [her]3254-the woman whom i had loved and lost that [I]74-mr. germaine should think of [her]3254-the woman whom i had loved and lost tenderly to the end of [my]74-mr. germaine life ? [[My]74-mr. germaine mother]365-my mother ’s delicate tact and true sympathy showed [me]74-mr. germaine the way . “[74-mr. germaine] Send a little present , [George]74-mr. germaine , ” [she]365-my mother said , “[74-mr. germaine] to [the child]2711-the child . [You]74-mr. germaine bear no malice to [the poor little child]1208-the poor little child ? ” God knows [I]74-mr. germaine was not hard on [the child]2711-the child ! [I]74-mr. germaine went out [myself]74-mr. germaine and bought [her]365-my mother a toy . [I]74-mr. germaine brought it [home]2233-home , and before [I]74-mr. germaine sent it away , [I]74-mr. germaine pinned a slip of paper to it , bearing this inscription : “[74-mr. germaine] To [[your]1209-your little daughter]1210-your little daughter , from [George Germaine]74-mr. germaine . ” There is nothing very pathetic , [I]74-mr. germaine suppose , in those words . And yet [I]74-mr. germaine burst out crying when [I]74-mr. germaine had written them . The next morning [[my]74-mr. germaine mother]365-my mother and [I]74-mr. germaine set forth for [[my]74-mr. germaine country - house in [Perthshire]12-perthshire]3260-my country - house in perthshire . [London]2-london was now unendurable to [me]74-mr. germaine . Traveling abroad [I]74-mr. germaine had tried already . Nothing was left but to go back to [the Highlands]3261-the highlands , and to try what [I]74-mr. germaine could make of [my]74-mr. germaine life , with [[my]74-mr. germaine mother]365-my mother still left to live for . THERE is something repellent to [me]74-mr. germaine , even at this distance of time , in looking back at the dreary days , of seclusion which followed each other monotonously in [[my]74-mr. germaine Highland home]3263-my highland home . The actions of [my]74-mr. germaine life , however trifling [they]3264-they may have been , [I]74-mr. germaine can find some interest in recalling : [they]3264-they associate [me]74-mr. germaine with [my]74-mr. germaine fellow - creatures ; [they]3264-they connect [me]74-mr. germaine , in some degree , with the vigorous movement of [the world]287-the world . But [I]74-mr. germaine have no sympathy with the purely selfish pleasure which [some men]3266-some men appear to derive from dwelling on the minute anatomy of [their]3266-some men own feelings , under the pressure of adverse fortune . Let the domestic record of [our]1211-our stagnant life in [Perthshire]12-perthshire ( so far as [I]74-mr. germaine am concerned in it ) be presented in [[my]74-mr. germaine mother]365-my mother ’s words , not in mine . A few lines of extract from the daily journal which it was [her]365-my mother habit to keep will tell all that need be told before this narrative advances to later dates and to newer scenes . “[74-mr. germaine] 20th August.—We have been two months at [[our]1211-our home in [Scotland]13-scotland]1212-our home in scotland , and [I]0-i see no change in [George]74-mr. germaine for the better . [He]74-mr. germaine is as far as ever , [I]0-i fear , from being reconciled to [his]74-mr. germaine separation from [that unhappy woman]1213-that unhappy woman . Nothing will induce [him]74-mr. germaine to confess it [himself]74-mr. germaine . [He]74-mr. germaine declares that [his]74-mr. germaine quiet life here with [me]0-i is all that [he]74-mr. germaine desires . But [I]0-i know better ! [I]0-i have been into [[his]74-mr. germaine bedroom]1214-his bedroom late at night . [I]0-i have heard [him]74-mr. germaine talking of [her]1213-that unhappy woman in [his]74-mr. germaine sleep , and [I]0-i have seen the tears on [his]74-mr. germaine eyelids . [[My]0-i poor boy]1215-my poor boy ! What [thousands of charming women there are who would ask nothing better than to be [[his]74-mr. germaine wife]215-his wife ! And [the one woman whom [he]74-mr. germaine can never marry]1218-the one woman whom he can never marry is [the only woman whom [he]74-mr. germaine loves]1219-the only woman whom he loves]1216-thousands of charming women there are who would ask nothing better than to be his wife ! and the one woman whom he can never marry is the only woman whom he loves ! “ 25th.—A long conversation about [George]74-mr. germaine with [Mr. MacGlue]104-mr. macglue . [I]74-mr. germaine have never liked [this Scotch doctor]3268-this scotch doctor since [he]3268-this scotch doctor encouraged [[my]74-mr. germaine son]574-my son to keep the fatal appointment at [[Saint Anthony]105-saint anthony ’s Well]836-saint anthony ’s well . But [he]74-mr. germaine seems to be [a clever man]3271-a clever man in [his]74-mr. germaine profession — and [I]74-mr. germaine think , in [his]74-mr. germaine way , [he]74-mr. germaine means kindly toward [George]74-mr. germaine . [His]3268-this scotch doctor advice was given as coarsely as usual , and very positively at the same time . ‘ Nothing will cure [[your]74-mr. germaine son]2257-your son , [madam]2256-madam , of [his]74-mr. germaine amatory passion for [that half - drowned lady of [his]74-mr. germaine but change]3274-that half - drowned lady of his but change — and [another lady]3275-another lady . Send [him]74-mr. germaine away by [himself]74-mr. germaine this time ; and let [him]74-mr. germaine feel the want of some kind creature to look after [him]74-mr. germaine . And when [he]74-mr. germaine meets with that kind creature ( [they]3276-they are as plenty as fish in [the sea]3277-the sea ) , never trouble [your]74-mr. germaine head about it if there ’s a flaw in [her]3274-that half - drowned lady of his but change character . [I]74-mr. germaine have got a cracked tea - cup which has served [me]74-mr. germaine for twenty years . Marry [him]74-mr. germaine , [ma’am]2244-ma’am , to the new one with the utmost speed and impetuosity which the law will permit . ’ [I]74-mr. germaine hate [Mr. MacGlue]104-mr. macglue ’s opinions — so coarse and so hard - hearted!—but [I]74-mr. germaine sadly fear that [I]74-mr. germaine must part with [[my]74-mr. germaine son]574-my son for a little while , for [his]74-mr. germaine own sake . “[74-mr. germaine] 26th.—Where is [George]74-mr. germaine to go ? [I]0-i have been thinking of it all through the night , and [I]0-i can not arrive at a conclusion . It is so difficult to reconcile [myself]0-i to letting [him]74-mr. germaine go away alone . “ [29th.—I]0-i have always believed in special providences ; and [I]1220-i am now confirmed in [my]1220-i belief . This morning has brought with it a note from [[our]0-i good friend and neighbor at [Belhelvie]39-belhelvie]3280-our good friend and neighbor at belhelvie . [Sir James]120-sir james is [one of [the commissioners for the Northern Lights]3282-the commissioners for the northern lights]3281-one of the commissioners for the northern lights . [He]120-sir james is going in [a Government vessel]3283-a government vessel to inspect [the lighthouses on [the North of [Scotland]13-scotland]2650-the north of scotland]3284-the lighthouses on the north of scotland , and on [the [Orkney]40-orkney and [Shetland Islands]41-shetland islands]3286-the orkney and shetland islands — and , having noticed how worn and ill [[my]1220-i poor boy]1215-my poor boy looks , [he]120-sir james most kindly invites [George]74-mr. germaine to be [[his]120-sir james guest]3288-his guest on the voyage . [They]3289-they will not be absent for more than two months ; and [the sea]3277-the sea ( as [Sir James]120-sir james reminds [me]1220-i ) did wonders for [George]74-mr. germaine ’s health when [he]74-mr. germaine returned from [India]9-india . [I]1220-i could wish for no better opportunity than this of trying what change of air and scene will do for [him]74-mr. germaine . However painfully [I]1220-i may feel the separation [myself]1220-i , [I]1220-i shall put a cheerful face on it ; and [I]1220-i shall urge [George]74-mr. germaine to accept the invitation . “[1220-i] [30th.—I]1220-i have said all [I]0-i could ; but [he]1221-i still refuses to leave [me]0-i . [I]0-i am [a miserable , selfish creature]1222-a miserable , selfish creature . [I]0-i felt so glad when [he]1221-i said No . “ 31st.—Another wakeful night . [George]74-mr. germaine must positively send [his]74-mr. germaine answer to [Sir James]120-sir james to - day . [I]1221-i am determined to do [my]1221-i duty toward [[my]1221-i son]574-my son — [he]74-mr. germaine looks so dreadfully pale and ill this morning ! Besides , if something is not done to rouse [him]74-mr. germaine , how do [I]1221-i know that [he]74-mr. germaine may not end in going back to [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt after all ? From every point of view , [I]1221-i feel bound to insist on [his]74-mr. germaine accepting [Sir James]120-sir james ’s invitation . [I]1221-i have only to be firm , and the thing is done . [He]74-mr. germaine has never yet disobeyed [me]1221-i , [poor fellow]3292-poor fellow . [He]74-mr. germaine will not disobey [me]1221-i now . “[1221-i] 2d [September.—He]121-september.—he has gone ! Entirely to please [me]0-i — entirely against [his]121-september.—he own wishes . Oh , how is it that [such a good son]1223-such a good son can not get [a good wife]1033-a good wife ! [He]1223-such a good son would make [any woman]1225-any woman happy . [I]0-i wonder whether [I]0-i have done right in sending [him]1223-such a good son away ? The wind is moaning in [the fir plantation]1226-the fir plantation at the back of [the house]258-the house . Is there a storm at [sea]625-sea ? [I]0-i forgot to ask [Sir James]120-sir james how big [the vessel]2622-the vessel was . The ‘ Guide to [Scotland]13-scotland ’ says [the coast]1230-the coast is rugged ; and there is [a wild sea]1231-a wild sea between [the north shore]1232-the north shore and [the Orkney Islands]42-the orkney islands . [I]0-i almost regret having insisted so strongly — how foolish [I]0-i am ! [We]1233-we are all in the hands of [God]93-god . May [God]93-god bless and prosper [[my]0-i good son]1234-my good son ! “ 10th.—Very uneasy . No letter from [George]74-mr. germaine . Ah , how full of trouble this life is ! and how strange that [we]1233-we should cling to it as [we]1233-we do ! “[93-god] 15th.—A letter from [George]74-mr. germaine ! [They]1235-they have done with [the north coast]1236-the north coast and [they]1235-they have crossed [the wild sea]1237-the wild sea to [the Orkneys]43-the orkneys . Wonderful weather has favored [them]1235-they so far ; and [George]74-mr. germaine is in better health and spirits . Ah ! how much happiness there is in life if [we]1233-we only have the patience to wait for it . “ 2d October.—Another letter . [They]1235-they are safe in [the harbor of [Lerwick]44-lerwick]3293-the harbor of lerwick , [the chief port in [the Shetland Islands]41-shetland islands]3294-the chief port in the shetland islands . The weather has not latterly been at all favorable . But the amendment in [George]74-mr. germaine ’s health remains . [He]74-mr. germaine writes most gratefully of [Sir James]120-sir james ’s unremitting kindness to [him]74-mr. germaine . [I]1238-the guide am so happy , [I]1238-the guide declare [I]1238-the guide could kiss [Sir James]120-sir james — though [he]120-sir james is [a great man]3295-a great man , and [a Commissioner for [Northern Lights]46-northern lights]3296-a commissioner for northern lights ! In three weeks more ( wind and weather permitting ) [they]1235-they hope to get back . Never mind [my]1238-the guide lonely life here , if [I]1238-the guide can only see [George]74-mr. germaine happy and well again ! [He]74-mr. germaine tells [me]1238-the guide [they]1235-they have passed a great deal of [their]1235-they time on [shore]3297-shore ; but not a word does [he]74-mr. germaine say about meeting [any ladies]3298-any ladies . Perhaps [they]1235-they are scarce in [those wild regions]3299-those wild regions ? [I]1238-the guide have heard of Shetland shawls and [Shetland]47-shetland ponies . Are there [any Shetland ladies]3300-any shetland ladies , [I]1238-the guide wonder ? ”[1238-the guide] “ [I]1238-the guide ca n’t say for certain . ”[1238-the guide] “ Have [you]1238-the guide lost [your]1238-the guide way ? ”[1238-the guide] [The guide]1238-the guide looks slowly all round [him]1238-the guide , and then looks at [me]0-i . That is [his]1238-the guide answer to [my]0-i question . And that is enough . [The lost persons]1239-the lost persons are three in number . [[My]0-i traveling companion]3104-my traveling companion , [myself]0-i , and [the guide]1238-the guide . [We]1242-we are seated on [three Shetland ponies]1243-three shetland ponies — so small in stature , that [[we]1242-we two strangers]1244-we two strangers were at first literally ashamed to get on [their]1243-three shetland ponies backs . [We]1242-we are surrounded by dripping white mist so dense that [we]1242-we become invisible to [one another at a distance of half a dozen yards]1245-one another at a distance of half a dozen yards . [We]1242-we know that [we]1242-we are somewhere on [the mainland of [the Shetland Isles]48-the shetland isles]1246-the mainland of the shetland isles . [We]1242-we see under the feet of [[our]1242-we ponies]1247-our ponies a mixture of moorland and bog — here , the strip of firm ground that [we]1242-we are standing on , and there , a few feet off , the strip of watery peat - bog , which is deep enough to suffocate [us]1242-we if [we]1242-we step into it . Thus far , and no further , [our]1242-we knowledge extends . This question of the moment is , What are [we]1242-we to do next ? [The guide]1238-the guide lights [his]1238-the guide pipe , and reminds [me]0-i that [he]1238-the guide warned [us]1242-we against the weather before [we]1242-we started for [our]1242-we ride . [[My]0-i traveling companion]3104-my traveling companion looks at [me]0-i resignedly , with an expression of mild reproach . [I]0-i deserve it . [My]0-i rashness is to blame for the disastrous position in which [we]1242-we now find [ourselves]1242-we . In writing to [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother , [I]0-i have been careful to report favorably of [my]0-i health and spirits . But [I]0-i have not confessed that [I]0-i still remember the day when [I]0-i parted with the one hope and renounced the one love which made life precious to [me]0-i . [My]0-i torpid condition of mind , at [home]2233-home , has simply given place to a perpetual restlessness , produced by the excitement of [my]0-i new life . [I]0-i must now always be doing something — no matter what , so long as it diverts [me]0-i from [my]0-i own thoughts . Inaction is unendurable ; solitude has become horrible to [me]0-i . While [the other members of the party which has accompanied [Sir James]120-sir james on [his]120-sir james voyage of inspection among [the lighthouses]1253-the lighthouses]1252-the other members of the party which has accompanied sir james on his voyage of inspection among the lighthouses are content to wait in [the harbor of [Lerwick]44-lerwick]3293-the harbor of lerwick for a favorable change in the weather , [I]0-i am obstinately bent on leaving [the comfortable shelter of [the vessel]2622-the vessel]1255-the comfortable shelter of the vessel to explore some inland ruin of prehistoric times , of which [I]0-i never heard , and for which [I]0-i care nothing . The movement is all [I]0-i want ; the ride will fill the hateful void of time . [I]0-i go , in defiance of sound advice offered to [me]0-i on all sides . [The youngest member of [our]1258-our party]1257-the youngest member of our party catches the infection of [my]0-i recklessness ( in virtue of [his]1257-the youngest member of our party youth ) and goes with [me]0-i . And what has come of it ? [We]1258-our are blinded by mist ; [we]1258-our are lost on [a moor]1259-a moor ; and [the treacherous peat - bogs]1260-the treacherous peat - bogs are round [us]1258-our in every direction ! What is to be done ? “ Just leave it to [the pownies]3301-the pownies , ”[1238-the guide] [the guide]1238-the guide says . “ Do [you]0-i mean leave the ponies to find the way ? ”[1238-the guide] “ That ’s it , ”[1238-the guide] says [the guide]1238-the guide . “ Drop the bridle , and leave it to [the pownies]3301-the pownies . See for [yourselves]3301-the pownies . [I]1238-the guide ’m away on [my]1238-the guide powny . ”[1238-the guide] [He]1238-the guide drops [his]1238-the guide bridle on the pommel of [his]1238-the guide saddle , whistles to [his]1238-the guide pony , and disappears in the mist ; riding with [his]1238-the guide hands in [his]1238-the guide pockets , and [his]1238-the guide pipe in [his]1238-the guide mouth , as composedly as if [he]1238-the guide were sitting by [his]1238-the guide own fireside at [home]2233-home . [We]1258-our have no choice but to follow [his]1238-the guide example , or to be left alone on [the moor]1264-the moor . The intelligent little animals , relieved from [our]1258-our stupid supervision , trot off with [their]1265-their noses to the ground , like hounds on the scent . Where [the intersecting tract of bog]1266-the intersecting tract of bog is wide , [they]1265-their skirt round [it]1266-the intersecting tract of bog . [Where]1267-where [it]1266-the intersecting tract of bog is narrow enough to be leaped over , [they]1265-their cross it by a jump . Trot ! trot!—away the hardy little creatures go ; never stopping , never hesitating . [Our]1258-our “ superior intelligence , ”[1238-the guide] perfectly useless in the emergency , wonders how it will end . [[Our]1258-our guide]1268-our guide , in front of [us]1258-our , answers that it will end in the ponies finding [their]1265-their way certainly to [the nearest village]1269-the nearest village or [the nearest house]1270-the nearest house . “ Let the bridles be , ”[1238-the guide] is [his]1238-the guide one warning to [us]1258-our . “ Come what may of it , let the bridles be ! ”[1238-the guide] It is easy for [the guide]1238-the guide to let [his]1238-the guide bridle be — [he]1238-the guide is accustomed to place [himself]1238-the guide in that helpless position under stress of circumstances , and [he]1238-the guide knows exactly what [his]1238-the guide pony can do . To [us]1258-our , however , the situation is a new one ; and it looks dangerous in the extreme . More than once [I]0-i check [myself]0-i , not without an effort , in the act of resuming the command of [my]0-i pony on passing the more dangerous points in the journey . The time goes on ; and no sign of an inhabited dwelling looms through the mist . [I]0-i begin to get fidgety and irritable ; [I]0-i find [myself]0-i secretly doubting the trustworthiness of [the guide]1238-the guide . While [I]0-i am in this unsettled frame of mind , [my]0-i pony approaches a dim , black , winding line , where [the bog]1273-the bog must be crossed for the hundredth time at least . The breadth of [it]1274-it ( deceptively enlarged in appearance by the mist ) looks to [my]0-i eyes beyond the reach of a leap by any pony that ever was foaled . [I]0-i lose [my]0-i presence of mind . At the critical moment before the jump is taken , [I]0-i am foolish enough to seize the bridle , and suddenly check the pony . [He]1238-the guide starts , throws up [his]1238-the guide head , and falls instantly as if [he]1238-the guide had been shot . [My]0-i right hand , as [we]1275-we drop on the ground together , gets twisted under [me]0-i , and [I]0-i feel that [I]0-i have sprained [my]0-i wrist . If [I]0-i escape with no worse injury than this , [I]0-i may consider [myself]0-i well off . But no such good fortune is reserved for [me]0-i . In [his]1238-the guide struggles to rise , before [I]0-i have completely extricated [myself]0-i from [him]1238-the guide , the pony kicks [me]0-i ; and , as [my]0-i ill - luck will have it , [his]1238-the guide hoof strikes just where the poisoned spear struck [me]0-i in the past days of [my]0-i service in [India]9-india . The old wound opens again — and there [I]0-i lie bleeding on [the barren Shetland moor]1276-the barren shetland moor ! This time [my]0-i strength has not been exhausted in attempting to breast the current of [a swift - flowing river]1277-a swift - flowing river with [a drowning woman to support]1278-a drowning woman to support . [I]0-i preserve [my]0-i senses ; and [I]0-i am able to give the necessary directions for bandaging the wound with the best materials which [we]1279-us have at [our]1279-us disposal . To mount [my]0-i pony again is simply out of the question . [I]0-i must remain where [I]0-i am , with [[my]0-i traveling companion]3104-my traveling companion to look after [me]0-i ; and [the guide]1238-the guide must trust [his]1238-the guide pony to discover the nearest place of shelter to which [I]0-i can be removed . Before [he]1238-the guide abandons [us]1279-us on [the moor]1264-the moor , [the man]2308-the man ( at [my]0-i suggestion ) takes [our]1279-us “ bearings , ”[2308-the man] as correctly as [he]2308-the man can by the help of [my]0-i pocket - compass . This done , [he]2308-the man disappears in the mist , with the bridle hanging loose , and the pony ’s nose to the ground , as before . [I]0-i am left , under [[my]0-i young friend]1284-my young friend ’s care , with a cloak to lie on , and a saddle for a pillow . [[Our]1279-us ponies]1247-our ponies composedly help [themselves]1247-our ponies to such grass as [they]1247-our ponies can find on [the moor]1264-the moor ; keeping always near [us]1279-us as companionably as if [they]1247-our ponies were a couple of dogs . In this position [we]1279-us wait events , while the dripping mist hangs thicker than ever all round [us]1279-us . The slow minutes follow each other wearily in the majestic silence of [the moor]1264-the moor . [We]1279-us neither of [us]1279-us acknowledge it in words , but [we]1279-us both feel that hours may pass before [the guide]1238-the guide discovers [us]1279-us again . The penetrating damp slowly strengthens its clammy hold on [me]0-i . [[My]0-i companion]946-my companion ’s pocket - flask of sherry has about a teaspoonful of wine left in the bottom of it . [We]1279-us look at [one another]200-one another — having nothing else to look at in the present state of the weather — and [we]1279-us try to make the best of it . So the slow minutes follow each other , until [our]1279-us watches tell [us]1279-us that forty minutes have elapsed since [the guide]1238-the guide and [his]1238-the guide pony vanished from [our]1279-us view . [[My]0-i friend]2203-my friend suggests that [we]1279-us may as well try what [our]1279-us voices can do toward proclaiming [our]1279-us situation to any living creature who may , by the barest possibility , be within hearing of [us]1279-us . [I]0-i leave [him]2203-my friend to try the experiment , having no strength to spare for vocal efforts of any sort . [[My]0-i companion]946-my companion shouts at the highest pitch of [his]946-my companion voice . Silence follows [his]946-my companion first attempt . [He]2203-my friend tries again ; and , this time , an answering hail reaches [us]1279-us faintly through the white fog . [A fellow - creature of some sort]1294-a fellow - creature of some sort , [guide]312-guide or [stranger]1296-stranger , is near [us]1279-us — help is coming at last ! Then [the guide]1238-the guide advances near enough to be identified . [I]0-i am , fortunately for [[my]0-i bearers]1311-my bearers , a light weight . [We]1392-we are evidently in the presence of [The Master of Books]3303-the master of books ! [THE little gentleman]1397-the little gentleman advances to [my]0-i bedside . [I]1397-the little gentleman ask the question a little abruptly , fearing that time may be of importance , and knowing that [[our]3316-our nearest doctor]3317-our nearest doctor lives at some distance from [this house]569-this house . ”[1397-the little gentleman] [He]1397-the little gentleman speaks with a certain quaintly precise choice of words — more like [a man dictating a letter]1399-a man dictating a letter than holding a conversation . [He]1397-the little gentleman and sorrow have apparently been [old acquaintances]1400-old acquaintances , and have become used to [each other]354-each other for years past . The shadow of some past grief rests quietly and impenetrably over [the whole man]1402-the whole man ; [I]0-i see it in [his]1397-the little gentleman faded blue eyes , on [his]1397-the little gentleman broad forehead , on [his]1397-the little gentleman delicate lips , on [his]1397-the little gentleman pale shriveled cheeks . [Mr. Dunross]122-mr. dunross looks at [me]0-i , as if [he]122-mr. dunross , like [the guide]1238-the guide , failed entirely to understand what [my]0-i scruples and excuses mean . A faint smile flickers over [his]1397-the little gentleman face ; [he]1397-the little gentleman lays [his]1397-the little gentleman hand in a gentle , fatherly way on [my]0-i shoulder . “ [We]1405-our are so used here to [our]1405-our Shetland hospitality , ”[1397-the little gentleman] [he]1397-the little gentleman says , “ that [we]1405-our are slow to understand the hesitation which [a stranger]2745-a stranger feels in taking advantage of it . [[Your]0-i guide]3320-your guide is in no respect to blame , [gentlemen]2213-gentlemen . [Every house in [these islands]3323-these islands which is large enough to contain [a spare room]3324-a spare room]3322-every house in these islands which is large enough to contain a spare room has [[its Guests]3325-its guests ’ Chamber]3326-its guests ’ chamber , always kept ready for occupation . When [you]0-i travel [my]1397-the little gentleman way , [you]0-i come here as a matter of course ; [you]0-i stay here as long as [you]0-i like ; and , when [you]0-i go away , [I]1397-the little gentleman only do [my]1397-the little gentleman duty as [a good Shetlander]3327-a good shetlander in accompanying [you]0-i on the first stage of [your]0-i journey to bid [you]0-i godspeed . [I]1397-the little gentleman beg of [you]0-i to give [[my]1397-the little gentleman servant]1000-my servant all the directions which are necessary to [your]0-i comfort , just as freely as [you]0-i could give them in [[your]0-i own house]3329-your own house . ”[1397-the little gentleman] [He]1409-he turns aside to ring a hand - bell on the table as [he]1409-he speaks ; and notices in [the guide]1238-the guide ’s face plain signs that [the man]2308-the man has taken offense at [my]0-i disparaging allusion to [him]1238-the guide . “ [Strangers]2712-strangers can not be expected to understand [our]3331-our ways , [Andrew]123-andrew , ”[3303-the master of books] says [The Master of Books]3303-the master of books . “ But [you]123-andrew and [I]3303-the master of books understand [one another]200-one another — and that is enough . ”[3303-the master of books] [The guide]1238-the guide ’s rough face reddens with pleasure . [He]1238-the guide makes a clumsy attempt to take [the Master]2287-the master ’s hand and kiss it . [We]1426-we take advantage of the momentary silence that follows to introduce [ourselves]1426-we by name to [[our]1426-we host]186-our host , and to inform [him]186-our host of the circumstances under which [we]1426-we happen to be visiting [Shetland]47-shetland . [He]186-our host listens in [his]186-our host subdued , courteous way ; but [he]186-our host makes no inquiries about [[our]1426-we relatives]1428-our relatives ; [he]186-our host shows no interest in the arrival of [the Government yacht]1429-the government yacht and [the Commissioner for Northern Lights]1430-the commissioner for northern lights . For twenty years the little round of [his]186-our host duties and [his]186-our host occupations has been enough for [him]186-our host . Life has lost its priceless value to [this man]2995-this man ; and when [Death]126-death comes to [him]2995-this man [he]2995-this man will receive [the king of terrors]1434-the king of terrors as [he]2995-this man might receive [the last of [[his]2995-this man guests]1436-his guests]1435-the last of his guests . “ Is there anything else [I]186-our host can do , ”[186-our host] [he]186-our host says , speaking more to [himself]186-our host than to [us]1437-us , “ before [I]186-our host go back to [my]186-our host books ? ”[186-our host] Something else occurs to [him]186-our host , even as [he]186-our host puts the question . The dishes are few in number , but cooked to perfection and admirably served . [I]0-i am too weary to eat much : a glass of the fine old Madeira revives [me]0-i . [We]1444-our arrange [our]1444-our future plans while [we]1444-our are engaged over the meal . [Our]1444-our return to [the yacht in [Lerwick]44-lerwick harbor]1447-the yacht in lerwick harbor is expected on the next day at the latest . These arrangements decided on , [[my]0-i friend]2203-my friend goes away ( at [my]0-i own request ) to try [his]2203-my friend skill as an angler in [the lake]289-the lake . Assisted by [the silent Peter]1454-the silent peter and the well - stocked medicine - chest , [I]0-i apply the necessary dressings to [my]0-i wound , wrap [myself]0-i in the comfortable morning - gown which is always kept ready in [[the Guests]1455-the guests ’ Chamber]1456-the guests ’ chamber , and lie down again on the bed to try the restorative virtues of sleep . Before [he]1454-the silent peter leaves [the room]185-the room , [silent Peter]124-peter goes to the window , and asks in fewest possible words if [he]1454-the silent peter shall draw the curtains . In fewer words still — for [I]0-i am feeling drowsy already — [I]0-i answer No . [I]0-i dislike shutting out the cheering light of day . To [my]0-i morbid fancy , at that moment , it looks like resigning [myself]0-i deliberately to the horrors of a long illness . The hand - bell is on [my]0-i bedside table ; and [I]0-i can always ring for [Peter]124-peter if the light keeps [me]0-i from sleeping . On this understanding , [Peter]124-peter mutely nods [his]124-peter head , and goes out . For some minutes [I]0-i lie in lazy contemplation of the companionable fire . Meanwhile the dressings on [my]0-i wound and the embrocation on [my]0-i sprained wrist steadily subdue the pains which [I]0-i have felt so far . Little by little , the bright fire seems to be fading . Little by little , sleep steals on [me]0-i , and all [my]0-i troubles are forgotten . [I]0-i wake , after what seems to have been a long repose — [I]0-i wake , feeling the bewilderment which [we]1458-we all experience on opening [our]1458-we eyes for the first time in a bed and [a room that are new to [us]1458-we]1459-a room that are new to us . Gradually collecting [my]0-i thoughts , [I]0-i find [my]0-i perplexity considerably increased by a trifling but curious circumstance . The curtains which [I]0-i had forbidden [Peter]124-peter to touch are drawn — closely drawn , so as to plunge [the whole room]1460-the whole room in obscurity . And , more surprising still , a high screen with folding sides stands before the fire , and confines the light which it might otherwise give exclusively to the ceiling . [I]0-i am literally enveloped in shadows . Has night come ? In lazy wonder , [I]0-i turn [my]0-i head on the pillow , and look on the other side of [my]0-i bed . Dark as it is , [I]0-i discover instantly that [I]0-i am not alone . [A shadowy figure]1461-a shadowy figure stands by [my]0-i bedside . The dim outline of the dress tells [me]0-i that it is the figure of [a woman]237-a woman . Straining [my]0-i eyes , [I]0-i fancy [I]0-i can discern a wavy black object covering [her]237-a woman head and shoulders which looks like a large veil . [Her]237-a woman face is turned toward [me]0-i , but no distinguishing feature in it is visible . [She]237-a woman stands like a statue , with [her]237-a woman hands crossed in front of [her]237-a woman , faintly relieved against the dark substance of [her]237-a woman dress . This [I]0-i can see — and this is all . There is a moment of silence . [The shadowy being]1463-the shadowy being finds [its]1463-the shadowy being voice , and speaks first . “ [I]1463-the shadowy being hope [you]0-i feel better , [sir]2230-sir , after [your]0-i rest ? ”[1463-the shadowy being] The voice is low , with a certain faint sweetness or tone which falls soothingly on [my]0-i ear . The accent is unmistakably the accent of [a refined and cultivated person]1464-a refined and cultivated person . [He]124-peter closed the curtains by [my]721-this lady order . ”[721-this lady] The reply puzzles [me]0-i . Why should [Peter]124-peter keep [the room]185-the room dark while [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross is in [it]185-the room ? Are [her]721-this lady eyes weak ? [[Your]0-i room]776-your room has been darkened — not on [your]0-i account , but on [mine]721-this lady . ”[721-this lady] [MISS DUNROSS]127-miss dunross had so completely perplexed [me]0-i , that [I]0-i was at a loss what to say next . To ask [her]721-this lady plainly why it was necessary to keep [the room]185-the room in darkness while [she]721-this lady remained in [it]185-the room , might prove ( for all [I]0-i knew to the contrary ) to be an act of positive rudeness . To venture on any general expression of sympathy with [her]721-this lady , knowing absolutely nothing of the circumstances , might place [us]1480-us both in an embarrassing position at the outset of [our]1480-us acquaintance . The one thing [I]0-i could do was to beg that the present arrangement of [the room]185-the room might not be disturbed , and to leave [her]721-this lady to decide as to whether [she]721-this lady should admit [me]0-i to [her]721-this lady confidence or exclude [me]0-i from it , at [her]721-this lady own sole discretion . [She]721-this lady perfectly understood what was going on in [my]0-i mind . Some time since , a dreadful illness raged among [the people in [[our]3364-our part of [this island]3366-this island]3365-our part of this island]3363-the people in our part of this island ; and [I]721-this lady was so unfortunate as to catch the infection . When [I]721-this lady recovered — no ! ‘ Recovery ’ is not the right word to use — let [me]721-this lady say , when [I]721-this lady escaped death , [I]721-this lady found [myself]721-this lady afflicted by a nervous malady which has defied medical help from that time to this . [I]721-this lady am suffering ( as [the doctors]3367-the doctors explain it to [me]721-this lady ) from a morbidly sensitive condition of the nerves near the surface to the action of light . If [I]721-this lady were to draw the curtains , and look out of that window , [I]721-this lady should feel the acutest pain all over [my]721-this lady face . If [I]721-this lady covered [my]721-this lady face , and drew the curtains with [my]721-this lady bare hands , [I]721-this lady should feel the same pain in [my]721-this lady hands . [You]3368-you can just see , perhaps , that [I]721-this lady have a very large and very thick veil on [my]721-this lady head . [I]721-this lady let it fall over [my]721-this lady face and neck and hands , when [I]721-this lady have occasion to pass along [the corridors]3369-the corridors or to enter [[[my]721-this lady father]315-my father ’s study]3371-my father ’s study — and [I]721-this lady find it protection enough . Do n’t be too ready to deplore [my]721-this lady sad condition , [sir]2230-sir ! [I]721-this lady have got so used to living in the dark that [I]721-this lady can see quite well enough for all the purposes of [my]721-this lady poor existence . [I]721-this lady can read and write in these shadows — [I]721-this lady can see [you]3368-you , and be of use to [you]3368-you in many little ways , if [you]3368-you will let [me]721-this lady . There is really nothing to be distressed about . [My]721-this lady life will not be a long one — [I]721-this lady know and feel that . But [I]721-this lady hope to be spared long enough to be [[my]721-this lady father]315-my father ’s companion through the closing years of [his]315-my father life . Beyond that , [I]721-this lady have no prospect . In the meanwhile , [I]721-this lady have [my]721-this lady pleasures ; and [I]721-this lady mean to add to [my]721-this lady scanty little stack the pleasure of attending on [you]3368-you . [You]3368-you are quite an event in [my]721-this lady life . [I]721-this lady look forward to reading to [you]3368-you and writing for [you]3368-you , as [some girls]3374-some girls look forward to a new dress , or a first ball . [I]721-this lady have been looking at [you]3368-you while [you]3368-you were asleep ; and [I]721-this lady have read [your]3368-you face as [I]721-this lady might read a book . [I]721-this lady am afraid [I]721-this lady shall trouble [you]3368-you with many questions about [yourself]3368-you when [we]3379-we become better acquainted with [each other]354-each other . [You]3368-you are able to raise [yourself]3368-you ? Wait a little . There ! Now lie back — and tell [me]721-this lady if [I]721-this lady know how to establish the right sort of sympathy between a tumbled pillow and a weary head . ”[721-this lady] [She]1483-her had so indescribably touched and interested [me]0-i , stranger as [I]0-i was , that the sudden cessation of [her]1483-her faint , sweet tones affected [me]0-i almost with a sense of pain . In trying ( clumsily enough ) to help [her]1483-her with the pillows , [I]0-i accidentally touched [her]1483-her hand . It felt so cold and so thin , that even the momentary contact with it startled [me]0-i . [I]0-i tried vainly to see [her]1483-her face , now that it was more within reach of [my]0-i range of view . The merciless darkness kept it as complete a mystery as ever . Had [my]0-i curiosity escaped [her]1483-her notice ? Nothing escaped [her]1483-her notice . [Her]1483-her next words told [me]0-i plainly that [I]0-i had been discovered . “ [You]0-i have been trying to see [me]1483-her , ”[1483-her] [she]1483-her said . “ Has [my]1483-her hand warned [you]0-i not to try again ? [I]1483-her felt that it startled [you]0-i when [you]0-i touched it just now . ”[1483-her] Such quickness of perception as this was not to be deceived ; such fearless candor demanded as a right a similar frankness on [my]0-i side . [I]0-i owned the truth , and left it to [her]1483-her indulgence to forgive [me]0-i . [She]1483-her returned slowly to [her]1483-her chair at the foot of the bed . “ If [we]3383-we are to be [friends]3384-friends , ”[1483-her] [she]1483-her said , “ [we]3383-we must begin by understanding [one another]200-one another . Do n’t associate any romantic ideas of invisible beauty with [me]1484-i , [Mr. Germaine]74-mr. germaine . [I]1484-i had but one beauty to boast of before [I]1484-i fell ill — [my]1484-i complexion — and that has gone forever . There is nothing to see in [me]1484-i now but the poor reflection of [my]1484-i former self ; the ruin of what was once [a woman]237-a woman . [I]1484-i do n’t say this to distress [you]3387-you — [I]1484-i say it to reconcile [you]3387-you to the darkness as a perpetual obstacle , so far as [your]3387-you eyes are concerned , between [you]3387-you and [me]1484-i . [Women]420-women , no doubt , generally do justice to the affectionate nature of cats . The streak of daylight being now excluded from [the room]185-the room , [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross threw back [her]127-miss dunross veil , and took the harp on [her]127-miss dunross knee ; seating [herself]127-miss dunross , [I]0-i observed , with [her]127-miss dunross face turned away from the fire . “ [You]0-i will have light enough to see the cats by , ”[127-miss dunross] [she]127-miss dunross said , “ without having too much light for [me]127-miss dunross . The sound was at first unpleasantly high in pitch , to [my]0-i untutored ear . At the opening notes of the melody — a slow , wailing , dirgelike air — the cats rose , and circled round [[their]1490-they mistress]1487-their mistress , marching to the tune . Now [they]1490-they followed [each other]354-each other singly ; now , at a change in the melody , [they]1490-they walked two and two ; and , now again , [they]1490-they separated into divisions of three each , and circled round the chair in opposite directions . The music quickened , and the cats quickened [their]1490-they pace with it . Faster and faster the notes rang out , and faster and faster in the ruddy firelight , the cats , like living shadows , whirled round the still black figure in the chair , with the ancient harp on its knee . Anything so weird , wild , and ghostlike [I]0-i never imagined before even in a dream ! The music changed , and the whirling cats began to leap . One perched itself at a bound on the pedestal of the harp . Four sprung up together , and assumed [their]1493-their places , two on each of [her]127-miss dunross shoulders . The last and smallest of the cats took the last leap , and lighted on [her]127-miss dunross head ! There [the six creatures]1494-the six creatures kept [their]1494-the six creatures positions , motionless as statues ! Nothing moved but the wan , white hands over the harp - strings ; no sound but the sound of the music stirred in [the room]185-the room . Once more the melody changed . [A woman]237-a woman , in [your]0-i place , would have parted with [her]237-a woman life rather than part with the one memorial left of the time when [she]237-a woman first loved ! ”[127-miss dunross] [She]127-miss dunross spoke with such extraordinary earnestness — with such agitation , [I]0-i might almost say — that [she]127-miss dunross quite startled [me]0-i . “ [Dear Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross , ”[0-i] [I]0-i remonstrated , “ the flag is not lost . ”[0-i] “ [I]127-miss dunross should hope not ! ”[127-miss dunross] [she]127-miss dunross interposed , quickly . “ If [you]0-i lose the green flag , [you]0-i lose the last relic of [Mary]85-mary — and more than that , if [my]127-miss dunross belief is right . ”[127-miss dunross] “ What do [you]127-miss dunross believe ? ”[0-i] “ [You]127-miss dunross will laugh at [me]0-i if [I]0-i tell [you]127-miss dunross . [I]0-i was sufficiently restored to be capable of making the journey to [Lerwick]44-lerwick , if [I]0-i rested for one night at [a farm half - way between [the town]1544-the town and [Mr. Dunross]122-mr. dunross ’s house]1543-a farm half - way between the town and mr. dunross ’s house . What emotion , what passion , had [she]127-miss dunross awakened in [me]0-i ? Was it love ? No : not love . [The place which [Mary]85-mary had once held in [my]0-i heart]1547-the place which mary had once held in my heart , [the place which [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt had taken in the after - time]1548-the place which mrs. van brandt had taken in the after - time , was not [the place occupied by [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross]1549-the place occupied by miss dunross . How could [I]0-i ( in the ordinary sense of the word ) be in love with [a woman whose face [I]0-i had never seen]1550-a woman whose face i had never seen ? whose beauty had faded , never to bloom again ? whose wasted life hung by a thread which the accident of a moment might snap ? The senses have [their]1551-their share in all love between the sexes which is worthy of the name . [They]1551-their had no share in the feeling with which [I]0-i regarded [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross . What was the feeling , then ? [I]0-i can only answer the question in one way . The feeling lay too deep in [me]0-i for [my]0-i sounding . What impression had [I]0-i produced on [her]127-miss dunross ? What sensitive chord had [I]0-i ignorantly touched , when [my]0-i lips touched [her]127-miss dunross hand ? [I]0-i confess [I]0-i recoiled from pursuing the inquiry which [I]0-i had deliberately set [myself]0-i to make . [I]0-i thought of [her]127-miss dunross shattered health ; of [her]127-miss dunross melancholy existence in shadow and solitude ; of the rich treasures of such a heart and such a mind as [hers]127-miss dunross , wasted with [her]127-miss dunross wasting life ; and [I]0-i said to [myself]0-i , Let [her]127-miss dunross secret be sacred ! let [me]0-i never again , by word or deed , bring the trouble which tells of it to the surface ! let [her]127-miss dunross heart be veiled from [me]0-i in the darkness which veils [her]127-miss dunross face ! In this frame of mind toward [her]127-miss dunross , [I]0-i waited [her]127-miss dunross return . [I]0-i had no doubt of seeing [her]127-miss dunross again , sooner or later , on that day . [The post to the south]1552-the post to the south went out on the next day ; and the early hour of the morning at which [the messenger]1553-the messenger called for [our]1554-our letters made it a matter of ordinary convenience to write overnight . In the disabled state of [my]0-i hand , [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross had been accustomed to write [home]2233-home for [me]0-i , under [my]0-i dictation : [she]127-miss dunross knew that [I]0-i owed a letter to [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother , and that [I]0-i relied as usual on [her]127-miss dunross help . [Her]127-miss dunross return to [me]0-i , under these circumstances , was simply a question of time : any duty which [she]127-miss dunross had once undertaken was an imperative duty in [her]127-miss dunross estimation , no matter how trifling it might be . The hours wore on ; the day drew to its end — and still [she]127-miss dunross never appeared . [I]0-i left [[my]0-i room]2363-my room to enjoy the last sunny gleam of the daylight in [the garden attached to [the house]258-the house]1558-the garden attached to the house ; first telling [Peter]124-peter where [I]0-i might be found , if [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross wanted [me]0-i . Slowly pursuing [my]0-i walk , [I]0-i proposed to [myself]0-i to occupy [my]0-i mind to some useful purpose by arranging beforehand the composition of the letter which [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross was to write . To [my]0-i great surprise , [I]0-i found it simply impossible to fix [my]0-i mind on the subject . Try as [I]0-i might , [my]0-i thoughts persisted in wandering from the letter to [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother , and concentrated themselves instead — on [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross ? No . On the question of [my]0-i returning , or not returning , to [Perthshire]12-perthshire by [the Government vessel]1542-the government vessel ? No . By some capricious revulsion of feeling which it seemed impossible to account for , [my]0-i whole mind was now absorbed on the one subject which had been hitherto so strangely absent from it — the subject of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt ! [My]0-i memory went back , in defiance of all exercise of [my]0-i own will , to [my]0-i last interview with [her]103-mrs. van brandt . [I]0-i saw [her]103-mrs. van brandt again ; [I]0-i heard [her]103-mrs. van brandt again . [I]0-i tasted once more the momentary rapture of [our]1568-our last kiss ; [I]0-i felt once more the pang of sorrow that wrung [me]0-i when [I]0-i had parted with [her]103-mrs. van brandt and found [myself]0-i alone in [the street]960-the street . Tears — of which [I]0-i was ashamed , though [nobody]2485-nobody was near to see [them]1571-them — filled [my]0-i eyes when [I]0-i thought of the months that had passed since [we]1568-our had last looked on [one another]200-one another , and of all that [she]103-mrs. van brandt might have suffered , must have suffered , in that time . This strange condition of [my]0-i mind was matched by an equally strange condition of [my]0-i body . A mysterious trembling shuddered over [me]0-i faintly from head to foot . [I]0-i walked without feeling the ground as [I]0-i trod on it ; [I]0-i looked about [me]0-i with no distinct consciousness of what the objects were on which [my]0-i eyes rested . [My]0-i hands were cold — and yet [I]0-i hardly felt it . [My]0-i head throbbed hotly — and yet [I]0-i was not sensible of any pain . It seemed as if [I]0-i were surrounded and enwrapped in some electric atmosphere which altered all the ordinary conditions of sensation . [I]0-i looked up at the clear , calm sky , and wondered if a thunderstorm was coming . [I]0-i stopped , and buttoned [my]0-i coat round [me]0-i , and questioned [myself]0-i if [I]0-i had caught a cold , or if [I]0-i was going to have a fever . The sun sank below the moorland horizon ; the gray twilight trembled over [the dark waters of [the lake]289-the lake]1574-the dark waters of the lake . [I]0-i went back to [the house]258-the house ; and the vivid memory of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt , still in close companionship , went back with [me]0-i .
