[She]1587-her spoke — but it was not to reply : it was only to change the subject . “ The time is passing , ”[1587-her] was all [she]1587-her said . “ [We]3478-we have not begun [your]1587-her letter to [[your]1587-her mother]2252-your mother yet . ”[1587-her] It would have been cruel to contend with [her]1587-her any longer . [Her]1587-her voice warned [me]0-i that [she]1587-her was suffering . The faint gleam of light through the parted curtains was fading fast . It was time , indeed , to write the letter . [I]0-i could find other opportunities of speaking to [her]1587-her before [I]0-i left [the house]258-the house . “ [I]0-i am ready , ”[0-i] [I]0-i answered . “ Let [us]3480-us begin . ”[0-i] The first sentence was easily dictated to [[my]0-i patient secretary]1589-my patient secretary . [I]0-i informed [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother that [my]0-i sprained wrist was nearly restored to use , and that nothing prevented [my]0-i leaving [Shetland]47-shetland when [the lighthouse commissioner]1591-the lighthouse commissioner was ready to return . This was all that it was necessary to say on the subject of [my]0-i health ; the disaster of [my]0-i re - opened wound having been , for obvious reasons , concealed from [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother ’s knowledge . [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross silently wrote the opening lines of the letter , and waited for the words that were to follow . In [my]0-i next sentence , [I]0-i announced the date at which [the vessel]2622-the vessel was to sail on the return voyage ; and [I]0-i mentioned the period at which [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother might expect to see [me]0-i , weather permitting . Those words , also , [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross wrote — and waited again . [I]0-i set [myself]0-i to consider what [I]0-i should say next . To [my]0-i surprise and alarm , [I]0-i found it impossible to fix [my]0-i mind on the subject . [My]0-i thoughts wandered away , in the strangest manner , from [my]0-i letter to [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt . [I]0-i was ashamed of [myself]0-i ; [I]0-i was angry with [myself]0-i — [I]0-i resolved , no matter what [I]0-i said , that [I]0-i would positively finish the letter . No ! try as [I]0-i might , the utmost effort of [my]0-i will availed [me]0-i nothing . [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt ’s words at [our]1595-our last interview were murmuring in [my]0-i ears — not a word of [my]0-i own would come to [me]0-i ! [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross laid down [her]127-miss dunross pen , and slowly turned [her]127-miss dunross head to look at [me]0-i . “ Surely [you]0-i have something more to add to [your]0-i letter ? ”[127-miss dunross] [she]127-miss dunross said . “ Certainly , ”[127-miss dunross] [I]0-i answered . “ [I]127-miss dunross do n’t know what is the matter with [me]127-miss dunross . The effort of dictating seems to be beyond [my]127-miss dunross power this evening . ”[127-miss dunross] “ Can [I]127-miss dunross help [you]0-i ? ”[127-miss dunross] [she]127-miss dunross asked . [I]0-i gladly accepted the suggestion . “ There are many things , ”[0-i] [I]0-i said , “ which [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother would be glad to hear , if [I]0-i were not too stupid to think of them . [I]0-i am sure [I]0-i may trust [your]0-i sympathy to think of them for [me]0-i . ”[0-i] That rash answer offered [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross the opportunity of returning to the subject of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt . [She]127-miss dunross seized the opportunity with [a woman]237-a woman ’s persistent resolution when [she]127-miss dunross has [her]127-miss dunross end in view , and is determined to reach it at all hazards . “ [You]0-i have not told [[your]0-i mother]2252-your mother yet , ”[127-miss dunross] [she]127-miss dunross said , “ that [your]0-i infatuation for [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt is at an end . [I]0-i thought to [myself]0-i indolently , “ If [I]0-i say No , [she]127-miss dunross will only return to the subject again , and [she]127-miss dunross will end ( after all [I]0-i owe to [her]127-miss dunross kindness ) in making [me]0-i say Yes . ”[0-i] Before [I]0-i could answer [her]127-miss dunross [she]127-miss dunross had realized [my]0-i anticipations . With the image of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt vividly present to [my]0-i mind , [I]0-i arranged the first words of the sentence which was to tell [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother that [my]0-i “ infatuation ”[103-mrs. van brandt] was at an end ! “ [You]365-my mother will be glad to hear , ”[0-i] [I]0-i began , “ that time and change are doing [their]3483-their good work . ”[0-i] [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross wrote the words , and paused in anticipation of the next sentence . The light faded and faded ; [the room]185-the room grew darker and darker . [I]0-i went on . “ [I]0-i hope [I]0-i shall cause [you]365-my mother no more anxiety , [[my]0-i dear mother]807-my dear mother , on the subject of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt . ”[0-i] In the deep silence [I]0-i could hear the pen of [[my]0-i secretary]1599-my secretary traveling steadily over the paper while it wrote those words . “ Have [you]365-my mother written ? ”[0-i] [I]0-i asked , as the sound of the pen ceased . “ [I]127-miss dunross have written , ”[127-miss dunross] [she]127-miss dunross answered , in [her]127-miss dunross customary quiet tones . [I]0-i went on again with [my]0-i letter . “ The days pass now , and [I]0-i seldom or never think of [her]127-miss dunross ; [I]0-i hope [I]0-i am resigned at last to the loss of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt . ”[0-i] As [I]0-i reached the end of the sentence , [I]0-i heard a faint cry from [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross . Looking instantly toward [her]127-miss dunross , [I]0-i could just see , in the deepening darkness , t hat [her]127-miss dunross head had fallen on the back of the chair . [My]0-i first impulse was , of course , to rise and go to [her]127-miss dunross . [I]0-i had barely got to [my]0-i feet , when some indescribable dread paralyzed [me]0-i on the instant . Supporting [myself]0-i against the chimney - piece , [I]0-i stood perfectly incapable of advancing a step . The effort to speak was the one effort that [I]0-i could make . “ Are [you]127-miss dunross ill ? ”[0-i] [I]0-i asked . [She]127-miss dunross was hardly able to answer [me]0-i ; speaking in a whisper , without raising [her]127-miss dunross head . “ [I]127-miss dunross am frightened , ”[127-miss dunross] [she]127-miss dunross said . “ What has frightened [you]0-i ? ”[127-miss dunross] [I]0-i heard [her]127-miss dunross shudder in the darkness . Instead of answering [me]0-i , [she]127-miss dunross whispered to [herself]127-miss dunross : “ What am [I]127-miss dunross to say to [him]3485-him ? ”[127-miss dunross] “ Tell [me]0-i what has frightened [you]127-miss dunross ? ”[0-i] [I]0-i repeated . “ [You]127-miss dunross know [you]127-miss dunross may trust [me]127-miss dunross with the truth . ”[127-miss dunross] [She]127-miss dunross rallied [her]127-miss dunross sinking strength . [She]127-miss dunross answered in these strange words : “ Something has come between [me]127-miss dunross and the letter that [I]127-miss dunross am writing for [you]0-i . ”[127-miss dunross] “ What is it ? ”[127-miss dunross] “ [I]127-miss dunross ca n’t tell [you]0-i . ”[127-miss dunross] “ Can [you]0-i see it ? ”[127-miss dunross] “ No . ”[127-miss dunross] “ Can [you]0-i feel it ? ”[127-miss dunross] “ Yes ! ”[127-miss dunross] “ What is it like ? ”[127-miss dunross] “ Like a breath of cold air between [me]127-miss dunross and the letter . ”[127-miss dunross] “ Has the window come open ? ”[127-miss dunross] “ The window is close shut . ”[127-miss dunross] “ And the door ? ”[127-miss dunross] “ The door is shut also — as well as [I]0-i can see . Make sure of it for [yourself]0-i . Where are [you]0-i ? What are [you]0-i doing ? ”[0-i] [I]0-i was looking toward the window . As [she]127-miss dunross spoke [her]127-miss dunross last words , [I]0-i was conscious of a change in that part of [the room]185-the room . In the gap between the parted curtains there was a new light shining ; not the dim gray twilight of Nature , but a pure and starry radiance , a pale , unearthly light . While [I]0-i watched it , the starry radiance quivered as if some breath of air had stirred it . When it was still again , there dawned on [me]0-i through the unearthly luster the figure of [a woman]237-a woman . By fine and slow gradations , it became more and more distinct . [I]0-i knew [the noble figure]1602-the noble figure ; [I]0-i knew the sad and tender smile . For the second time [I]0-i stood in the presence of the apparition of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt . [She]127-miss dunross was robed , not as [I]0-i had last seen [her]127-miss dunross , but in the dress which [she]127-miss dunross had worn on the memorable evening when [we]1603-we met on [the bridge]2727-the bridge — in the dress in which [she]127-miss dunross had first appeared to [me]0-i , by [the waterfall in [Scotland]13-scotland]1605-the waterfall in scotland . The starry light shone round [her]127-miss dunross like a halo . [She]127-miss dunross looked at [me]0-i with sorrowful and pleading eyes , as [she]127-miss dunross had looked when [I]0-i saw the apparition of [her]127-miss dunross in [the summer - house]2869-the summer - house . [She]127-miss dunross lifted [her]127-miss dunross hand — not beckoning [me]0-i to approach [her]127-miss dunross , as before , but gently signing to [me]0-i to remain where [I]0-i stood . [I]0-i waited — feeling awe , but no fear . [My]0-i heart was all [hers]127-miss dunross as [I]0-i looked at [her]127-miss dunross . [She]127-miss dunross moved ; gliding from the window to the chair in which [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross sat ; winding [her]127-miss dunross way slowly round it , until [she]127-miss dunross stood at the back . By the light of the pale halo that encircled the ghostly Presence , and moved with it , [I]0-i could see the dark figure of [the living woman]1607-the living woman seated immovable in the chair . The writing - case was on [her]127-miss dunross lap , with the letter and the pen lying on it . [Her]127-miss dunross arms hung helpless at [her]127-miss dunross sides ; [her]127-miss dunross veiled head was now bent forward . [She]127-miss dunross looked as if [she]127-miss dunross had been struck to stone in the act of trying to rise from [her]127-miss dunross seat . A moment passed — and [I]0-i saw the ghostly Presence stoop over [the living woman]1607-the living woman . [It]1609-it lifted the writing - case from [her]127-miss dunross lap . [It]1609-it rested the writing - case on [her]127-miss dunross shoulder . Its white fingers took the pen and wrote on the unfinished letter . [It]1609-it put the writing - case back on the lap of [the living woman]1607-the living woman . Still standing behind the chair , it turned toward [me]0-i . [It]1609-it looked at [me]0-i once more . And now it beckoned — beckoned to [me]0-i to approach . Moving without conscious will of [my]0-i own , as [I]0-i had moved when [I]0-i first saw [her]127-miss dunross in [the summer - house]2869-the summer - house — drawn nearer and nearer by an irresistible power — [I]0-i approached and stopped within a few paces of [her]127-miss dunross . [She]127-miss dunross advanced and laid [her]127-miss dunross hand on [my]0-i bosom . Again [I]0-i felt those strangely mingled sensations of rapture and awe , which had once before filled [me]0-i when [I]0-i was conscious , spiritually , of [her]127-miss dunross touch . [I]0-i saw the twilight glimmering between the curtains — and [I]0-i saw no more . [She]127-miss dunross had spoken . [She]127-miss dunross had gone . [I]0-i was near [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross — near enough , when [I]0-i put out [my]0-i hand , to touch [her]127-miss dunross . Who could interpret the mysterious sympathies that still united [us]1630-us , in defiance of distance , in defiance of time ? Who could predict to what end [our]1630-us lives were tending in the years that were to come ? Those questions were still present to [my]0-i thoughts ; [my]0-i eyes were still fixed on the mysterious writing — when [I]0-i became instinctively aware of the strange silence in [the room]185-the room . [I]0-i was alone in [the room]185-the room . Why had [she]127-miss dunross left [me]0-i secretly , without a word of farewell ? Because [she]127-miss dunross was suffering , in mind or body ? Or because [she]127-miss dunross resented , naturally resented , [my]0-i neglect of [her]127-miss dunross ? The bare suspicion that [I]0-i had given [her]127-miss dunross pain was intolerable to [me]0-i . [I]0-i rang [my]0-i bell , to make inquiries . Left by [myself]0-i again , [I]0-i read the letter . It began , without any form of address , in these lines : “ [I]1644-you write , instead of speaking to [you]1644-you , because [my]1644-you self - control has already been severely tried , and [I]1644-you am not strong enough to bear more . [I]0-i do not stop to inquire whether [we]1648-we are both [the victims of a delusion]1649-the victims of a delusion , or whether [we]1648-we are [the chosen recipients of a supernatural communication]1650-the chosen recipients of a supernatural communication . The result , in either case , is enough for [me]0-i . [You]1644-you are once more under the influence of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt . [I]0-i will not trust [myself]0-i to tell [you]1644-you of the anxieties and forebodings by which [I]0-i am oppressed : [I]0-i will only acknowledge that [my]0-i one hope for [you]1644-you is in [your]1644-you speedy reunion with the worthier object of [your]1644-you constancy and devotion . [I]0-i still believe , and [I]0-i am consoled in believing , that [you]1644-you and [[your]1644-you first love]1651-your first love will meet again . “ Having written so far , [I]0-i leave the subject — not to return to it , except in [my]0-i own thoughts . “[0-i] The necessary preparations for [your]1644-you departure to - morrow are all made . Nothing remains but to wish [you]1644-you a safe and pleasant journey [home]2233-home . Do not , [I]0-i entreat [you]1644-you , think [me]0-i insensible of what [I]0-i owe to [you]1644-you , if [I]0-i say [my]0-i farewell words here . “ The little services which [you]1644-you have allowed [me]0-i to render [you]1644-you have brightened the closing days of [my]0-i life . [You]1644-you have left [me]0-i a treasury of happy memories which [I]0-i shall hoard , when [you]1644-you are gone , with miserly care . Are [you]1644-you willing to add new claims to [my]0-i grateful remembrance ? [I]0-i ask it of [you]1644-you , as a last favor — do not attempt to see [me]0-i again ! Do not expect [me]0-i to take a personal leave of [you]1644-you ! The saddest of all words is ‘ Good - by ’ : [I]0-i have fortitude enough to write it , and no more . God preserve and prosper [you]1644-you — farewell ! “[0-i] One more request . [I]0-i beg that [you]1653-you will not forget what [you]1653-you promised [me]0-i , when [I]0-i told [you]1653-you [my]0-i foolish fancy about the green flag . Wherever [you]1653-you go , let [Mary]85-mary ’s keepsake go with [you]1653-you . No written answer is necessary — [I]0-i would rather not receive it . Look up , when [you]1653-you leave [the house]258-the house to - morrow , at the center window over the doorway — that will be answer enough . ” To say that these melancholy lines brought the tears into [my]1653-you eyes is only to acknowledge that [I]1653-you had sympathies which could be touched . When [I]1653-you had in some degree recovered [my]1653-you composure , the impulse which urged [me]1653-you to write to [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross was too strong to be resisted . [I]1653-you did not trouble [her]127-miss dunross with a long letter ; [I]1653-you only entreated [her]127-miss dunross to reconsider [her]127-miss dunross decision with all the art of persuasion which [I]1653-you could summon to help [me]1653-you . The answer was brought back by [the servant who waited on [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross]3491-the servant who waited on miss dunross , in four resolute words : “[1653-you] It can not be . ” This time [the woman]2309-the woman spoke out before [she]2309-the woman left [me]1653-you . “[1653-you] If [you]1653-you have any regard for [[my]0-i mistress]549-my mistress , ” [she]0-i said sternly , “[1653-you] do n’t make [her]549-my mistress write to [you]1653-you again . ” [She]127-miss dunross looked at [me]3303-the master of books with a last lowering frown , and left [the room]185-the room . It is needless to say that [the faithful servant]3494-the faithful servant ’s words only increased [my]3303-the master of books anxiety to see [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross once more before [we]3495-we parted — perhaps forever . [My]3303-the master of books one last hope of success in attaining this object lay in approaching [her]127-miss dunross indirectly through the intercession of [[her]127-miss dunross father]390-her father . [I]3303-the master of books sent [Peter]124-peter to inquire if [I]3303-the master of books might be permitted to pay [my]3303-the master of books respects to [[his]124-peter master]2390-his master that evening . [[My]3303-the master of books messenger]3498-my messenger returned with an answer that was a new disappointment to [me]3303-the master of books . [Mr. Dunross]122-mr. dunross begged that [I]3303-the master of books would excuse [him]122-mr. dunross , if [he]122-mr. dunross deferred the proposed interview until the next morning . The next morning was the morning of [my]3303-the master of books departure . Did the message mean that [he]122-mr. dunross had no wish to see [me]3303-the master of books again until the time had come to take leave of [him]122-mr. dunross ? [I]3303-the master of books inquired of [Peter]124-peter whether [[his]124-peter master]2390-his master was particularly occupied that evening . [He]124-peter was unable to tell [me]3303-the master of books . “[3303-the master of books] [The Master of Books]3303-the master of books ” was not in [[his]124-peter study]3500-his study , as usual . When [he]124-peter sent [his]124-peter message to [me]3303-the master of books , [he]124-peter was sitting by the sofa in [[[his]124-peter daughter]437-his daughter ’s room]3502-his daughter ’s room . Having answered in those terms , [the man]2308-the man left [me]3303-the master of books by [myself]3303-the master of books until the next morning . [I]3303-the master of books do not wish [[my]3303-the master of books bitterest enemy]3504-my bitterest enemy a sadder time in [his]3504-my bitterest enemy life than the time [I]3303-the master of books passed during the last night of [[my]3303-the master of books residence]3505-my residence under [[Mr. Dunross]122-mr. dunross ’s roof]3506-mr. dunross ’s roof . After walking to and fro in [the room]185-the room until [I]3303-the master of books was weary , [I]3303-the master of books thought of trying to divert [my]3303-the master of books mind from the sad thoughts that oppressed it by reading . The one candle which [I]3303-the master of books had lighted failed to sufficiently illuminate [the room]185-the room . Advancing to the mantel - piece to light the second candle which stood there , [I]3303-the master of books noticed the unfinished letter to [[my]3303-the master of books mother]365-my mother lying where [I]3303-the master of books had placed it , when [[Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross ’s servant]3510-miss dunross ’s servant first presented [herself]3510-miss dunross ’s servant before [me]3303-the master of books . Having lighted the second candle , [I]3303-the master of books took up the letter to put it away among [my]3303-the master of books other papers . Doing this ( while [my]3303-the master of books thoughts were still dwelling on [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross ) , [I]3303-the master of books mechanically looked at the letter again — and instantly discovered a change in it . The written characters traced by the hand of [the apparition]2911-the apparition had vanished ! Below the last lines written by [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross nothing met [my]3303-the master of books eyes now but the blank white paper ! [My]3303-the master of books first impulse was to look at [my]3303-the master of books watch . When the ghostly presence had written in [my]3303-the master of books sketch - book , the characters had disappeared after an interval of three hours . On this occasion , as nearly as [I]3303-the master of books could calculate , the writing had vanished in one hour only . Reverting to the conversation which [I]3303-the master of books had held with [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt when [we]3512-we met at [Saint Anthony ’s Well]105-saint anthony , and to the discoveries which followed at a later period of [my]3303-the master of books life , [I]3303-the master of books can only repeat that [she]103-mrs. van brandt had again been the subject of a trance or dream , when the apparition of [her]103-mrs. van brandt showed itself to [me]3303-the master of books for the second time . As before , [she]103-mrs. van brandt had freely trusted [me]3303-the master of books and freely appealed to [me]3303-the master of books to help [her]103-mrs. van brandt , in the dreaming state , when [her]103-mrs. van brandt spirit was free to recognize [my]3303-the master of books spirit . When [she]103-mrs. van brandt had come to [herself]103-mrs. van brandt , after an interval of an hour , [she]103-mrs. van brandt had again felt ashamed of the familiar manner in which [she]103-mrs. van brandt had communicated with [me]3303-the master of books in the trance — had again unconsciously counteracted by [her]103-mrs. van brandt waking - will the influence of [her]103-mrs. van brandt sleeping - will ; and had thus caused the writing once more to disappear , in an hour from the moment when the pen had traced ( or seemed to trace ) it . This is still the one explanation that [I]3303-the master of books can offer . At the time when the incident happened , [I]3303-the master of books was far from being fully admitted to the confidence of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt ; and [I]3303-the master of books was necessarily incapable of arriving at any solution of the mystery , right or wrong . [I]3303-the master of books could only put away the letter , doubting vaguely whether [my]3303-the master of books own senses had not deceived [me]3303-the master of books . After the distressing thoughts which [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross ’s letter had roused in [my]3303-the master of books mind , [I]3303-the master of books was in no humor to employ [my]3303-the master of books ingenuity in finding a clew to the mystery of the vanished writing . [My]3303-the master of books nerves were irritated ; [I]3303-the master of books felt a sense of angry discontent with [myself]3303-the master of books and with [others]2521-others . “[3303-the master of books] Go where [I]0-i may ” ( [I]3303-the master of books thought impatiently ) , “[3303-the master of books] the disturbing influence of [women]420-women seems to be the only influence that [I]0-i am fated to feel . ” As [I]93-god still paced backward and forward in [[my]93-god room]2363-my room — it was useless to think now of fixing [my]93-god attention on a book — [I]93-god fancied [I]93-god understood the motives which made [men]1109-men as young as [I]93-god was retire to end [their]1109-men lives in [a monastery]3516-a monastery . [I]93-god drew aside the window curtains , and looked out . The only prospect that met [my]93-god view was the black gulf of darkness in which [the lake]289-the lake lay hidden . [I]93-god could see nothing ; [I]93-god could do nothing ; [I]93-god could think of nothing . The one alternative before [me]93-god was that of trying to sleep . [My]93-god medical knowledge told [me]93-god plainly that natural sleep was , in [my]93-god nervous condition , one of the unattainable luxuries of life for that night . The medicine - chest which [Mr. Dunross]122-mr. dunross had placed at [my]93-god disposal remained in [the room]185-the room . [I]93-god mixed for [myself]93-god a strong sleeping draught , and sullenly took refuge from [my]93-god troubles in bed . It is a peculiarity of most of the soporific drugs that they not only act in a totally different manner on different constitutions , but that they are not even to be depended on to act always in the same manner on [the same person]3519-the same person . [I]93-god had taken care to extinguish the candles before [I]93-god got into [my]93-god bed . Under ordinary circumstances , after [I]93-god had lain quietly in the darkness for half an hour , the draught that [I]93-god had taken would have sent [me]93-god to sleep . In the present state of [my]93-god nerves the draught stupefied [me]93-god , and did no more . Hour after hour [I]93-god lay perfectly still , with [my]93-god eyes closed , in the semi - sleeping , semi - wakeful state which is so curiously characteristic of the ordinary repose of a dog . As the night wore on , such a sense of heaviness oppressed [my]93-god eyelids that it was literally impossible for [me]93-god to open them — such a masterful languor possessed all [my]93-god muscles that [I]93-god could no more move on [my]93-god pillow than if [I]93-god had been a corpse . And yet , in this somnolent condition , [my]93-god mind was able to pursue lazy trains of pleasant thought . [My]93-god sense of hearing was so acute that it caught the faintest sounds made by the passage of the night - breeze through the rushes of [the lake]289-the lake . Inside [my]93-god bed - chamber , [I]93-god was even more keenly sensible of those weird night - noises in the heavy furniture of [a room]980-a room , of those sudden settlements of extinct coals in the grate , so familiar to [bad sleepers]3522-bad sleepers , so startling to overwrought nerves ! It is not a scientifically correct statement , but it exactly describes [my]93-god condition , that night , to say that [one half of [me]93-god]3523-one half of me was asleep and [the other half]3524-the other half awake . How many hours of the night had passed , when [my]93-god irritable sense of hearing became aware of a new sound in [the room]185-the room , [I]93-god can not tell . [I]93-god can only relate that [I]93-god found [myself]93-god on a sudden listening intently , with fast - closed eyes . The sound that disturbed [me]93-god was the faintest sound imaginable , as of something soft and light traveling slowly over the surface of the carpet , and brushing it just loud enough to be heard . Little by little , the sound came nearer and nearer to [my]93-god bed — and then suddenly stopped just as [I]93-god fancied it was close by [me]93-god . [I]93-god still lay immovable , with closed eyes ; drowsily waiting for the next sound that might reach [my]93-god ears ; drowsily content with the silence , if the silence continued . [My]93-god thoughts ( if thoughts they could be called ) were drifting back again into their former course , when [I]93-god became suddenly conscious of soft breathing just above [me]93-god . The next moment [I]93-god felt a touch on [my]93-god forehead — light , soft , tremulous , like the touch of lips that had kissed [me]93-god . There was a momentary pause . Then a low sigh trembled through the silence . Then [I]93-god heard again the still , small sound of something brushing its way over the carpet ; traveling this time from [my]93-god bed , and moving so rapidly that in a moment more it was lost in the silence of the night . Still stupefied by the drug that [I]93-god had taken , [I]93-god could lazily wonder what had happened , and [I]93-god could do no more . Had living lips really touched [me]93-god ? Was the sound that [I]93-god had heard really the sound of a sigh ? Or was it all delusion , beginning and ending in a dream ? The time passed without [my]93-god deciding , or caring to decide , those questions . Minute by minute , the composing influence of the draught began at last to strengthen its hold on [my]93-god brain . A cloud seemed to pass softly over [my]93-god last waking impressions . One after another , the ties broke gently that held [me]93-god to conscious life . [I]93-god drifted peacefully into perfect sleep . Shortly after sunrise , [I]93-god awoke . When [I]93-god regained the use of [my]93-god memory , [my]93-god first clear recollection was the recollection of the soft breathing which [I]93-god had felt above [me]93-god — then of the touch on [my]93-god forehead , and of the sigh which [I]93-god had heard after it . Was it possible that [some one]3526-some one had entered [[my]93-god room]2363-my room in the night ? It was quite possible . [I]93-god had not locked the door — [I]93-god had never been in the habit of locking the door during [[my]93-god residence under [Mr. Dunross]122-mr. dunross ’s roof]3528-my residence under mr. dunross ’s roof . After thinking it over a little , [I]93-god rose to examine [[my]93-god room]2363-my room . Nothing in the shape of a discovery rewarded [me]93-god , until [I]93-god reached the door . Though [I]93-god had not locked [it]3530-it overnight , [I]93-god had certainly satisfied [myself]93-god that [it]3530-it was closed before [I]93-god went to bed . It was now ajar . Had it opened again , through being imperfectly shut ? or had [a person]3531-a person , after entering and leaving [[my]93-god room]2363-my room , forgotten to close [it]3530-it ? Accidentally looking downward while [I]93-god was weighing these probabilities , [I]93-god noticed a small black object on the carpet , lying just under the key , on the inner side of the door . [I]93-god picked the thing up , and found that it was a torn morsel of black lace . The instant [I]93-god saw the fragment , [I]93-god was reminded of the long black veil , hanging below [her]3533-her waist , which it was the habit of [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross to wear . Was it [her]3533-her dress , then , that [I]93-god had heard softly traveling over the carpet ; [her]3533-her kiss that had touched [my]93-god forehead ; [her]3533-her sigh that had trembled through the silence ? Had [the ill - fated and noble creature]3534-the ill - fated and noble creature taken [her]3533-her last leave of [me]93-god in the dead of night , trusting the preservation of [her]3533-her secret to the deceitful appearances which persuaded [her]3533-her that [I]93-god was asleep ? [I]93-god looked again at the fragment of black lace . [Her]3533-her long veil might easily have been caught , and torn , by the projecting key , as [she]3533-her passed rapidly through the door on [her]3533-her way out of [[my]93-god room]2363-my room . Sadly and reverently [I]93-god laid the morsel of lace among the treasured memorials which [I]93-god had brought with [me]93-god from [home]2233-home . To the end of [her]3533-her life , [I]93-god vowed it , [she]3533-her should be left undisturbed in the belief that [her]3533-her secret was safe in [her]3533-her own breast ! Ardently as [I]93-god still longed to take [her]3533-her hand at parting , [I]93-god now resolved to make no further effort to see [her]3533-her . [I]93-god might not be master of [my]93-god own emotions ; something in [my]93-god face or in [my]93-god manner might betray [me]93-god to [her]3533-her quick and delicate perception . Knowing what [I]93-god now knew , the last sacrifice [I]93-god could make to [her]3533-her would be to obey [her]3533-her wishes . [I]93-god made the sacrifice . In an hour more [Peter]124-peter informed [me]93-god that [the ponies]1309-the ponies were at the door , and that [the Master]2287-the master was waiting for [me]93-god in [the outer hall]3539-the outer hall . [I]93-god noticed that [Mr. Dunross]122-mr. dunross gave [me]93-god [his]122-mr. dunross hand , without looking at [me]93-god . [His]122-mr. dunross faded blue eyes , during the few minutes while [we]3540-we were together , were not once raised from the ground . “[93-god] [God]93-god speed [you]1658-you on [your]1658-you journey , [sir]2230-sir , and guide [you]1658-you safely [home]2233-home , ” [he]122-mr. dunross said . “[93-god] [I]0-i beg [you]1658-you to forgive [me]0-i if [I]0-i fail to accompany [you]1658-you on the first few miles of [your]1658-you journey . There are reasons which oblige [me]0-i to remain with [[my]0-i daughter]1204-my daughter in [the house]258-the house . ” [He]122-mr. dunross was scrupulously , almost painfully , courteous ; but there was something in [his]122-mr. dunross manner which , for the first time in [my]1663-you experience , seemed designedly to keep [me]1663-you at a distance from [him]122-mr. dunross . Knowing the intimate sympathy , the perfect confidence , which existed between [the father]1372-the father and [daughter]2405-daughter , a doubt crossed [my]1663-you mind whether the secret of the past night was entirely a secret to [Mr. Dunross]122-mr. dunross . [His]122-mr. dunross next words set that doubt at rest , and showed [me]1663-you the truth . In thanking [him]122-mr. dunross for [his]122-mr. dunross good wishes , [I]1663-you attempted also to express to [him]122-mr. dunross ( and through [him]122-mr. dunross to [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross ) [my]1663-you sincere sense of gratitude for the kindness which [I]1663-you had received under [his]122-mr. dunross roof . [He]122-mr. dunross stopped [me]1663-you , politely and resolutely , speaking with that quaintly precise choice of language which [I]1663-you h ad remarked as characteristic of [him]122-mr. dunross at [our]3543-our first interview . “[1663-you] It is in [your]1663-you power , [sir]2230-sir , ” [he]122-mr. dunross said , “[1663-you] to return any obligation which [you]1663-you may think [you]1663-you have incurred on leaving [[my]0-i house]576-my house . If [you]1663-you will be pleased to consider [[your]1663-you residence [here]586-here]1666-your residence here as an unimportant episode in [your]1663-you life , which ends — absolutely ends — with [your]1663-you departure , [you]1663-you will more than repay any kindness that [you]1663-you may have received as [[my]0-i guest]3341-my guest . In saying this , [I]0-i speak under a sense of duty which does entire justice to [you]1663-you as [a gentleman]971-a gentleman and [a man of honor]1670-a man of honor . In return , [I]0-i can only trust to [you]1663-you not to misjudge [my]0-i motives , if [I]0-i abstain from explaining [myself]0-i any further . ” A faint color flushed [his]2230-sir pale cheeks . [He]2230-sir waited , with a certain proud resignation , for [my]0-i reply . [I]0-i respected [her]3544-her secret , respected it more resolutely than ever , before [[her]3544-her father]390-her father . “[0-i] After all that [I]0-i owe to [you]0-i , [sir]2230-sir , ” [I]0-i answered , “[0-i] [your]0-i wishes are [my]0-i commands . ” Saying that , and saying no more , [I]1672-my bowed to [him]2230-sir with marked respect , and left [the house]258-the house . Mounting [my]1672-my pony at the door , [I]1672-my looked up at the center window , as [she]3544-her had bidden [me]1672-my . It was open ; but dark curtains , jealously closed , kept out the light from [the room within]3547-the room within . At the sound of the pony ’s hoofs on [the rough island road]3548-the rough island road , as the animal moved , the curtains were parted for a few inches only . Through the gap in the dark draperies a wan white hand appeared ; waved tremulously a last farewell ; and vanished from [my]1672-my view . The curtains closed again on [her]3544-her dark and solitary life . The dreary wind sounded its long , low dirge over [the rippling waters of [the lake]289-the lake]3549-the rippling waters of the lake . [The ponies]1309-the ponies took [their]1309-the ponies places in [the ferryboat]3552-the ferryboat which was kept for the passage of animals to and from [the island]1375-the island . With slow , regular strokes [the men]1335-the men rowed [us]3555-our to [the mainland]3556-the mainland and took [their]1335-the men leave . [I]1672-my looked back at [the distant house]3557-the distant house . [I]1672-my thought of [her]3544-her in [the dark room]3558-the dark room , waiting patiently for death . Burning tears blinded [me]1672-my . [The guide]1238-the guide took [my]1672-my bridle in [his]1238-the guide hand : “[1672-my] [You]1672-my ’re not well , [sir]2230-sir , ” [he]1238-the guide said ; “[2230-sir] [I]0-i will lead the pony . ” When [I]1672-my looked again at [the landscape round [me]1672-my]3560-the landscape round me , [we]3555-our had descended in the interval from the higher ground to the lower . [The house]258-the house and [the lake]289-the lake had disappeared , to be seen no more . [I]1672-my had left [her]3544-her for [my]1672-my sea - voyage very unwillingly — seeing that [she]3544-her was in delicate health . On [my]1672-my return , [I]1672-my was grieved to observe a change for the worse , for which [her]3544-her letters had not prepared [me]1672-my . Consulting [[our]3555-our medical friend]3563-our medical friend , [Mr. MacGlue]104-mr. macglue , [I]1672-my found that [he]104-mr. macglue , too , had noticed [[my]1672-my mother]365-my mother ’s failing health , but that [he]104-mr. macglue attributed it to an easily removable cause — to the climate of [Scotland]13-scotland . [[My]1672-my mother]365-my mother ’s childhood and early life had been passed on [the southern shores of [England]1-england]3566-the southern shores of england . The change to the raw , keen air of [the North]51-the north had been a trying change to [a person]3531-a person at [her]365-my mother age . In [Mr. MacGlue]104-mr. macglue ’s opinion , the wise course to take would be to return to [the South]52-the south before the autumn was further advanced , and to make [our]3555-our arrangements for passing the coming winter at [Penzance]53-penzance or [Torquay]54-torquay . Resolved as [I]1672-my was to keep the mysterious appointment which summoned [me]1672-my to [London]2-london at the month ’s end , [Mr. MacGlue]104-mr. macglue ’s suggestion met with no opposition on [my]1672-my part . It had , to [my]1672-my mind , the great merit of obviating the necessity of a second separation from [[my]1672-my mother]365-my mother — assuming that [she]365-my mother approved of [the doctor]364-the doctor ’s advice . [I]1672-my put the question to [her]365-my mother the same day . To [my]1672-my infinite relief , [she]365-my mother was not only ready , but eager to take the journey to [the South]3570-the south . The season had been unusually wet , even for [Scotland]13-scotland ; and [[my]1672-my mother]365-my mother reluctantly confessed that [she]365-my mother “[1672-my] did feel a certain longing ” for the mild air and genial sunshine of [the Devonshire coast]3572-the devonshire coast . [We]3573-we arranged to travel in [[our]3573-we own comfortable carriage]3574-our own comfortable carriage by post — resting , of course , at inns on [the road]2726-the road at night . In the days before railways it was no easy matter for [an invalid]2628-an invalid to travel from [Perthshire]12-perthshire to [London]2-london — even with [a light carriage]3577-a light carriage and four horses . Calculating [our]3573-we rate of progress from the date of [our]3573-we departure , [I]2230-sir found that [we]3573-we had just time , and no more , to reach [London]2-london on the last day of the month . [I]2230-sir shall say nothing of the secret anxieties which weighed on [my]2230-sir mind , under these circumstances . Happily for [me]2230-sir , on every account , [[my]2230-sir mother]365-my mother ’s strength held out . The easy and ( as [we]3573-we then thought ) the rapid rate of traveling had its invigorating effect on [her]365-my mother nerves . [She]365-my mother slept better when [we]3573-we rested for the night than [she]365-my mother had slept at [home]2233-home . After twice being delayed on [the road]2726-the road , [we]3573-we arrived in [London]2-london at three o’clock on the afternoon of the last day of the month . Had [I]2230-sir reached [my]2230-sir destination in time ? As [I]2230-sir interpreted the writing of the apparition , [I]2230-sir had still some hours at [my]2230-sir disposal . The phrase , “[2230-sir] at the month ’s end , ” meant , as [I]2230-sir understood it , at the last hour of the last day in the month . If [I]2230-sir took up [my]2230-sir position “[2230-sir] under the shadow of [Saint Paul ’s]129-saint paul , ” say , at ten that night , [I]2230-sir should arrive at [the place of meeting]3581-the place of meeting with two hours to spare , before the last stroke of the clock marked the beginning of the new month . At half - past nine , [I]2230-sir left [[my]2230-sir mother]365-my mother to rest after [her]365-my mother long journey , and privately quit [the house]258-the house . Before ten , [I]2230-sir was at [[my]2230-sir post]3584-my post . The night was fine and clear ; and the huge shadow of [the cathedral]3585-the cathedral marked distinctly the limits within which [I]2230-sir had been bid to wait , on the watch for events . The great clock of [Saint Paul ’s]129-saint paul struck ten — and nothing happened . The next hour passed very slowly . [I]2230-sir walked up and down ; at one time absorbed in [my]2230-sir own thoughts ; at another , engaged in watching the gradual diminution in the number of foot passengers who passed [me]2230-sir as the night advanced . [The City]2410-the city ( as [it]2410-the city is called ) is [the most populous part of [London]2-london]3587-the most populous part of london in the daytime ; but at night , when [it]2410-the city ceases to be [the center of commerce]3588-the center of commerce , [its]2410-the city busy population melts away , and [the empty streets]3589-the empty streets assume the appearance of [a remote and deserted quarter of [the metropolis]3591-the metropolis]3590-a remote and deserted quarter of the metropolis . As the half hour after ten struck — then the quarter to eleven — then the hour — [the pavement]3592-the pavement steadily became more and more deserted . [I]2230-sir could count [the foot passengers]3593-the foot passengers now by twos and threes ; and [I]2230-sir could see [the places of public refreshment within [my]2230-sir view]3594-the places of public refreshment within my view beginning already to close for the night . [I]2230-sir looked at the clock ; it pointed to ten minutes past eleven . At that hour , could [I]2230-sir hope to meet [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt alone in [the public street]3595-the public street ? The more [I]2230-sir thought of it , the less likely such an event seemed to be . The more reasonable probability was that [I]2230-sir might meet [her]103-mrs. van brandt once more , accompanied by [some friend]3596-some friend — perhaps under the escort of [Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt [himself]103-mrs. van brandt . [I]2230-sir wondered whether [I]2230-sir should preserve [my]2230-sir self - control , in the presence of [that man]572-that man , for the second time . While [my]2230-sir thoughts were still pursuing this direction , [my]2230-sir attention was recalled to passing events by a sad little voice , putting a strange little question , close at [my]2230-sir side . “[2230-sir] If [you]1674-you please , [sir]2230-sir , do [you]1674-you know where [I]0-i can find [[a chemist]1676-a chemist ’s shop]1677-a chemist ’s shop open at this time of night ? ” [I]1674-you looked round , and discovered [a poorly clad little boy]3598-a poorly clad little boy , with a basket over [his]3598-a poorly clad little boy arm , and a morsel of paper in [his]3598-a poorly clad little boy hand . “[1674-you] [The chemists ’ shops]1678-the chemists ’ shops are all shut , ” [I]1674-you said . “[1674-you] If [you]1674-you want any medicine , [you]1674-you must ring the night - bell . ” “[0-i] [I]0-i dursn’t do it , [sir]2230-sir , ” replied [the small stranger]3599-the small stranger . “[0-i] [I]0-i am such [a little boy]1680-a little boy , [I]0-i ’m afraid of [their]1681-their beating [me]0-i if [I]0-i ring [them]1681-their up out of [[their]1681-their beds]1682-their beds , without [somebody]793-somebody to speak for [me]0-i . ” [The little creature]3600-the little creature looked at [me]793-somebody under the street lamp with such a forlorn experience of being beaten for trifling offenses in [his]3600-the little creature face , that it was impossible to resist the impulse to help [him]3600-the little creature . “[793-somebody] Is it a serious case of illness ? ” [I]0-i asked . “[0-i] [I]0-i do n’t know , [sir]2230-sir . ” “[0-i] Have [you]0-i got [a doctor]1685-a doctor ’s prescription ? ” [He]2230-sir held out [his]2230-sir morsel of paper . “[1685-a doctor] [I]0-i have got this , ” [he]2230-sir said . [I]130-mrs. brand took the paper from [him]2230-sir , and looked at it . It was an ordinary prescription for a tonic mixture . [I]130-mrs. brand looked first at [the doctor]364-the doctor ’s signature ; it was the name of [a perfectly obscure person in the profession]3602-a perfectly obscure person in the profession . Below it was written the name of [the patient for whom the medicine had been prescribed]3603-the patient for whom the medicine had been prescribed . [I]130-mrs. brand started as [I]130-mrs. brand read it . The name was “[130-mrs. brand] [Mrs. Brand]130-mrs. brand . ” The idea instantly struck [me]130-mrs. brand that this ( so far as sound went , at any rate ) was the English equivalent of [Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt . “[130-mrs. brand] Do [you]2230-sir know [the lady who sent [you]2230-sir for the medicine]1686-the lady who sent you for the medicine ? ” [I]2230-sir asked . “[2230-sir] Oh yes , [sir]2230-sir ! [She]1686-the lady who sent you for the medicine lodges with [mother]805-mother — and [she]1686-the lady who sent you for the medicine owes for rent . [I]0-i have done everything [she]1686-the lady who sent you for the medicine told [me]0-i , except getting the physic . [The boy]580-the boy showed [himself]580-the boy to [me]2244-ma’am at the door . “[2244-ma’am] Please to come in , [sir]2230-sir . [I]0-i ca n’t make anything of [her]1750-your mamma . ” It would have been misplaced delicacy to have hesitated any longer to enter [the room]185-the room . [I]0-i went in . There , at the opposite end of [a miserably furnished [bed - chamber]3680-bed - chamber , lying back feebly in a tattered old arm - chair]3679-a miserably furnished bed - chamber , lying back feebly in a tattered old arm - chair , was one more among the thousands of forlorn creatures , starving that night in [the great city]3681-the great city . A white handkerchief was laid over [her]1750-your mamma face as if to screen it from the flame of the fire hard by . [She]1750-your mamma lifted the handkerchief , startled by the sound of [my]0-i footsteps as [I]0-i entered [the room]185-the room . [I]0-i looked at [her]1750-your mamma , and saw in the white , wan , death - like face the face of [the woman [I]0-i loved]1628-the woman i loved ! For a moment the horror of the discovery turned [me]0-i faint and giddy . In another instant [I]0-i was kneeling by [her]1750-your mamma chair . [My]0-i arm was round [her]1750-your mamma — [her]1750-your mamma head lay on [my]0-i shoulder . [She]1750-your mamma was past speaking , past crying out : [she]1750-your mamma trembled silently , and that was all . [I]0-i said nothing . No words passed [my]0-i lips , no tears came to [my]0-i relief . [I]0-i held [her]1750-your mamma to [me]0-i ; and [she]1750-your mamma let [me]0-i hold [her]1750-your mamma . [The child]2711-the child , devouring [its]2711-the child bread - and - butter at a little round table , stared at [us]3685-us . [The boy]580-the boy , on [his]580-the boy knees before the grate , mending the fire , stared at [us]3685-us . And the slow minutes lagged on ; and the buzzing of a fly in a corner was the only sound in [the room]185-the room . The instincts of the profession to which [I]0-i had been trained , rather than any active sense of the horror of the situation in which [I]0-i was placed , roused [me]0-i at last . [She]1750-your mamma was starving ! [I]0-i saw it in the deadly color of [her]1750-your mamma skin ; [I]0-i felt it in the faint , quick flutter of [her]1750-your mamma pulse . [I]0-i called [the boy]580-the boy to [me]0-i , and sent [him]580-the boy to [the nearest public - house]3689-the nearest public - house for wine and biscuits . “[0-i] Be quick about it , ” [I]0-i said ; “[0-i] and [you]1754-you shall have more money for [yourself]1754-you than ever [you]1754-you had in [your]1754-you life ! ” [The boy]580-the boy looked at [me]0-i , spit on the coins in [his]580-the boy hand , said , “[0-i] That ’s for luck ! ” and ran out of [the room]185-the room as [never boy]3692-never boy ran yet . [I]0-i turned to speak [my]0-i first words of comfort to [the mother]1743-the mother . The cry of [the child]2711-the child stopped [me]0-i . “[0-i] [I]0-i ’m so hungry ! [I]0-i ’m so hungry ! ” [I]0-i set more food before [the famished child]3695-the famished child and kissed [her]3695-the famished child . [She]3695-the famished child looked up at [me]0-i with wondering eyes . “[0-i] Are [you]0-i [a new papa]1755-a new papa ? ” [the little creature]3600-the little creature asked . “[0-i] [[My]0-i other papa]1756-my other papa never kisses [me]0-i . ” [I]0-i looked at [the mother]1743-the mother . [Her]1743-the mother eyes were closed ; the tears flowed slowly over [her]1743-the mother worn , white cheeks . [I]0-i took [her]1743-the mother frail hand in [mine]0-i . “[0-i] Happier days are coming , ” [I]0-i said ; “[0-i] [you]0-i are [my]0-i care now . ” There was no answer . [She]1743-the mother still trembled silently , and that was all . In less than five minutes [the boy]580-the boy returned , and earned [his]580-the boy promised reward . [He]580-the boy sat on the floor by the fire counting [his]580-the boy treasure , [the one happy creature in [the room]185-the room]3699-the one happy creature in the room . [I]0-i soaked some crumbled morsels of biscuit in the wine , and , little by little , [I]0-i revived [her]1743-the mother failing strength by nourishment administered at intervals in that cautious form . After a while [she]1743-the mother raised [her]1743-the mother head , and looked at [me]0-i with wondering eyes that were pitiably like the eyes of [[her]1743-the mother child]3247-her child . A faint , delicate flush began to show itself in [her]1743-the mother face . [She]1743-the mother spoke to [me]0-i , for the first time , in whispering tones that [I]0-i could just hear as [I]0-i sat close at [her]1743-the mother side . “[0-i] How did [you]1757-you find [me]0-i ? Who showed [you]1757-you the way to [this place]1758-this place ? ” [She]1743-the mother paused ; painfully recalling the memory of something that was slow to come back . [Her]1743-the mother color deepened ; [she]1743-the mother found the lost remembrance , and looked at [me]1757-you with a timid curiosity . “[1757-you] What brought [you]1757-you [here]586-here ? ” [she]1743-the mother asked . “[1757-you] Was it [my]0-i dream ? ” “[0-i] Wait , dearest , till [you]1757-you are stronger , and [I]0-i will tell [you]1757-you all . ” [I]1760-i lifted [her]1743-the mother gently , and laid [her]1743-the mother on the wretched bed . [The child]2711-the child followed [us]3703-us , and climbing to the bedstead with [my]1760-i help , nestled at [[her]2711-the child mother]1190-her mother ’s side . [I]1760-i sent [the boy]580-the boy away to tell [the mistress of [the house]258-the house]3706-the mistress of the house that [I]1760-i should remain with [[my]1760-i patient]3708-my patient , watching [her]3708-my patient progress toward recovery , through the night . [He]580-the boy went out , jingling [his]580-the boy money joyfully in [his]580-the boy pocket . [We]3703-us three were left together . As the long hours followed [each other]354-each other , [she]1743-the mother fell at intervals into a broken sleep ; waking with a start , and looking at [me]1760-i wildly as if [I]1760-i had been [a stranger]2745-a stranger at [her]1743-the mother bedside . Toward morning the nourishment which [I]1760-i still carefully administered wrought its healthful change in [her]1743-the mother pulse , and composed [her]1743-the mother to quieter slumbers . When the sun rose [she]1743-the mother was sleeping as peacefully as [the child at [her]1743-the mother side]3711-the child at her side . [I]1760-i was able to leave [her]1743-the mother , until [my]1760-i return later in the day , under the care of [the woman of [the house]258-the house]3712-the woman of the house . The magic of money transformed [this termagant and terrible person]3714-this termagant and terrible person into [a docile and attentive nurse]3715-a docile and attentive nurse — so eager to follow [my]1760-i instructions exactly that [she]1743-the mother begged [me]1760-i to commit them to writing before [I]1760-i went away . For a moment [I]1760-i still lingered alone at the bedside of [the sleeping woman]3716-the sleeping woman , and satisfied [myself]1760-i for the hundredth time that [her]1743-the mother life was safe , before [I]1760-i left [her]1743-the mother . It was the sweetest of all rewards to feel sure of this — to touch [her]1743-the mother cool forehead lightly with [my]1760-i lips — to look , and look again , at the poor worn face , always dear , always beautiful , to [my]1760-i eyes . change as it might . [I]1760-i closed the door softly and went out in the bright morning , [a happy man]3717-a happy man again . So close together rise the springs of joy and sorrow in human life ! So near in [our]3718-our heart , as in [our]3718-our heaven , is the brightest sunshine to the blackest cloud ! [I]1760-i REACHED [[my]1760-i own house]3719-my own house in time to snatch two or three hours of repose , before [I]1760-i paid [my]1760-i customary morning visit to [[my]1760-i mother]365-my mother in [[her]1743-the mother own room]3721-her own room . [I]1760-i observed , in [her]1743-the mother reception of [me]1760-i on this occasion , certain peculiarities of look and manner which were far from being familiar in [my]1760-i experience of [her]1743-the mother . When [our]3718-our eyes first met , [she]1743-the mother regarded [me]1760-i with a wistful , questioning look , as if [she]1743-the mother were troubled by some doubt which [she]1743-the mother shrunk from expressing in words . And when [I]1760-i inquired after [her]1743-the mother health , as usual , [she]1743-the mother surprised [me]1760-i by answering as impatiently as if [she]1743-the mother resented [my]1760-i having mentioned the subject . For a moment , [I]1760-i was inclined to think these changes signified that [she]1743-the mother had discovered [my]1760-i absence from [home]2233-home during the night , and that [she]1743-the mother had some suspicion of the true cause of it . But [she]1743-the mother never alluded , even in the most distant manner , to [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt ; and not a word dropped from [her]1743-the mother lips which implied , directly or indirectly , that [I]1760-i had pained or disappointed [her]1743-the mother . [I]1760-i could only conclude that [she]1743-the mother had something important to say in relation to [herself]1743-the mother or to [me]1760-i — and that for reasons of [her]1743-the mother own [she]1743-the mother unwillingly abstained from giving expression to it at that time . Reverting to [our]3723-we ordinary topics of conversation , [we]3723-we touched on the subject ( always interesting to [[my]1760-i mother]365-my mother ) of [my]1760-i visit to [Shetland]47-shetland . Speaking of this , [we]3723-we naturally spoke also of [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross . Here , again , when [I]1760-i least expected it , there was another surprise in store for [me]1760-i . “[1760-i] [You]1760-i were talking the other day , ” said [[my]1760-i mother]365-my mother , “[1760-i] of the green flag which [poor [Dermody]85-mary ’s daughter]1761-poor dermody ’s daughter worked for [you]1760-i , when [you]1760-i were [both children]1762-both children . Have [you]1760-i really kept it all this time ? ” “[1760-i] Yes . ” “[1760-i] Where have [you]1760-i left it ? In [Scotland]13-scotland ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i have brought it with [me]0-i to [London]2-london . ” “[0-i] Why ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i promised [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross to take the green flag with [me]0-i , wherever [I]0-i might go . ” [[My]0-i mother]365-my mother smiled . “[0-i] Is it possible , [George]74-mr. germaine , that [you]74-mr. germaine think about this as [the young lady in [Shetland]47-shetland]1763-the young lady in shetland thinks ? After all the years that have passed , [you]74-mr. germaine believe in the green flag being the means of bringing [Mary Dermody]85-mary and [yourself]74-mr. germaine together again ? ” “[74-mr. germaine] Certainly not ! [I]0-i am only humoring one of the fancies of poor [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross . Could [I]0-i refuse to grant [her]127-miss dunross trifling request , after all [I]0-i owed to [her]127-miss dunross kindness ? ” The smile left [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother ’s face . [She]365-my mother looked at [me]0-i attentively . “[0-i] [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross seems to have produced a very favorable impression on [you]74-mr. germaine , ” [she]365-my mother said . “[0-i] [I]0-i own it . [I]0-i feel deeply interested in [her]127-miss dunross . ” “[0-i] If [she]127-miss dunross had not been [an incurable invalid]3473-an incurable invalid , [George]74-mr. germaine , [I]0-i too might have become interested in [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross — perhaps in the character of [[my]0-i daughter - in - law]1765-my daughter - in - law ? ” “[127-miss dunross] It is useless , [mother]805-mother , to speculate on what might have happened . The sad reality is enough . ” [[My]127-miss dunross mother]365-my mother paused a little before [she]365-my mother put [her]365-my mother next question to [me]127-miss dunross . “[127-miss dunross] Did [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross always keep [her]127-miss dunross veil drawn in [your]74-mr. germaine presence , when there happened to be light in [the room]185-the room ? ” “[127-miss dunross] Always . ” “[127-miss dunross] [She]127-miss dunross never even let [you]74-mr. germaine catch a momentary glance at [her]127-miss dunross face ? ” “[127-miss dunross] Never . ” “[127-miss dunross] And the only reason [she]127-miss dunross gave [you]74-mr. germaine was that the light caused [her]127-miss dunross a painful sensation if it fell on [her]127-miss dunross uncovered skin ? ” “[74-mr. germaine] [You]74-mr. germaine say that , [mother]805-mother , as if [you]74-mr. germaine doubt whether [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross told [me]0-i the truth . ” “[127-miss dunross] No , [George]74-mr. germaine . [I]0-i only doubt whether [she]127-miss dunross told [you]74-mr. germaine all the truth . ” “[127-miss dunross] What do [you]74-mr. germaine mean ? ” “[74-mr. germaine] Do n’t be offended , [[my]0-i dear]657-my dear . [I]0-i believe [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross has some more serious reason for keeping [her]127-miss dunross face hidden than the reason that [she]127-miss dunross gave [you]74-mr. germaine . ” [I]127-miss dunross was silent . The suspicion which those words implied had never occurred to [my]127-miss dunross mind . [I]127-miss dunross had read in medical books of cases of morbid nervous sensitiveness exactly similar to the case of [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross , as described by [herself]127-miss dunross — and that had been enough for [me]127-miss dunross . Now that [[my]127-miss dunross mother]365-my mother ’s idea had found its way from [her]365-my mother mind to [mine]127-miss dunross , the impression produced on [me]127-miss dunross was painful in the last degree . Horrible imaginings of deformity possessed [my]127-miss dunross brain , and profaned all that was purest and dearest in [my]127-miss dunross recollections of [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross . It was useless to change the subject — the evil influence that was on [me]127-miss dunross was too potent to be charmed away by talk . Making the best excuse that [I]127-miss dunross could think of for leaving [[[my]127-miss dunross mother]365-my mother ’s room]3731-my mother ’s room , [I]127-miss dunross hurried away to seek a refuge from [myself]127-miss dunross , where alone [I]127-miss dunross could hope to find it , in the presence of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt . [THE landlady]2791-the landlady was taking the air at [her]2791-the landlady own door when [I]127-miss dunross reached [the house]258-the house . [Her]2791-the landlady reply to [my]127-miss dunross inquiries justified [my]127-miss dunross most hopeful anticipations . [The poor lodger]3734-the poor lodger looked already “[127-miss dunross] like [another woman]629-another woman ” ; and [the child]2711-the child was at that moment posted on the stairs , watching for the return of [[her]2711-the child “[127-miss dunross] new papa]3736-her “ new papa . ” “[127-miss dunross] There ’s one thing [I]0-i should wish to say to [you]1771-you , [sir]2230-sir , before [you]1771-you go [upstairs]665-upstairs , ” [the woman]2309-the woman went on . “[2230-sir] Do n’t trust [the lady]2202-the lady with more money at a time than the money that is wanted for the day ’s housekeeping . If [she]2202-the lady has any to spare , it ’s as likely as not to be wasted on [[her]2202-the lady good - for - nothing husband]1775-her good - for - nothing husband . ” Absorbed in the higher and dearer interests that filled [my]1775-her good - for - nothing husband mind , [I]1775-her good - for - nothing husband had thus far forgotten the very existence of [Mr. Van Brandt]102-mr. van brandt . “[1775-her good - for - nothing husband] Where is [he]1775-her good - for - nothing husband ? ” [I]1775-her good - for - nothing husband asked . “[1775-her good - for - nothing husband] Where [he]1775-her good - for - nothing husband ought to be , ” was the answer . “[1775-her good - for - nothing husband] In prison for debt . ” In those days [a man imprisoned for debt]3738-a man imprisoned for debt was not infrequently [a man imprisoned for life]3739-a man imprisoned for life . There was little fear of [my]135-mamma visit being shortened by the appearance on the scene of [Mr. Van Brandt]102-mr. van brandt . Ascending [the stairs]3167-the stairs , [I]135-mamma found [the child]2711-the child waiting for [me]135-mamma on [the upper landing]3742-the upper landing , with a ragged doll in [her]2711-the child arms . [I]135-mamma had bought a cake for [her]2711-the child on [my]135-mamma way to [the house]258-the house . [She]2711-the child forthwith turned over the doll to [my]135-mamma care , and , trotting before [me]135-mamma into [the room]185-the room with [her]2711-the child cake in [her]2711-the child arms , announced [my]135-mamma arrival in these words : “[135-mamma] [Mamma]135-mamma , [I]0-i like [this papa]1776-this papa better than the other . [You]135-mamma like [him]1776-this papa better , too . ” [The mother]1743-the mother ’s wasted face reddened for a moment , then turned pale again , as [she]2711-the child held out [her]2711-the child hand to [me]135-mamma . [I]135-mamma looked at [her]2711-the child anxiously , and discerned the welcome signs of recovery , clearly revealed . [Her]2711-the child grand gray eyes rested on [me]135-mamma again with a glimmer of their old light . The hand that had lain so cold in [mine]135-mamma on the past night had life and warmth in it now . “[135-mamma] Should [I]0-i have died before the morning if [you]135-mamma had not come [here]586-here ? ” [she]2711-the child asked , softly . “[0-i] Have [you]135-mamma saved [my]0-i life for the second time ? [I]0-i can well believe it . ” Before [I]135-mamma was aware of [her]2711-the child , [she]2711-the child bent [her]2711-the child head over [my]135-mamma hand , and touched it tenderly with [her]2711-the child lips . “[135-mamma] [I]0-i am not [an ungrateful woman]3079-an ungrateful woman , ” [she]2711-the child murmured—“and[0-i] yet [I]0-i do n’t know how to thank [you]135-mamma . ” [The child]2711-the child looked up quickly from [her]2711-the child cake . “[0-i] Why do n’t [you]135-mamma kiss [him]1779-him ? ” [the quaint little creature]3747-the quaint little creature asked , with a broad stare of astonishment . Further away than [Scotland]13-scotland — as far away as [Shetland]47-shetland . ” “[135-mamma] Tell [me]0-i about it ! Pray , pray tell [me]0-i about it ! ” [I]135-mamma related what had happened as exactly as [I]135-mamma could , consistently with maintaining the strictest reserve on one point . Concealing from [her]2711-the child the very existence of [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross , [I]135-mamma left [her]2711-the child to suppose that [the master of [the house]258-the house]3748-the master of the house was [the one person whom [I]135-mamma had found to receive [me]135-mamma during [my]135-mamma sojourn under [[Mr. Dunross]122-mr. dunross ’s roof]3506-mr. dunross ’s roof]3750-the one person whom i had found to receive me during my sojourn under mr. dunross ’s roof . “[135-mamma] That is strange ! ” [she]2711-the child exclaimed , after [she]2711-the child had heard [me]135-mamma attentively to the end . “[135-mamma] What is strange ? ” [I]135-mamma asked . [I]1787-a lady in the house put the question in a form which left [me]1787-a lady in the house free to decide whether [I]1787-a lady in the house should take [her]2711-the child unreservedly into [my]1787-a lady in the house confidence or not . “[1787-a lady in the house] Am [I]0-i right , ” [I]0-i began , “[0-i] in supposing that [you]1789-you dreamed of [me]0-i in [Shetland]47-shetland , as [you]1789-you once before dreamed of [me]0-i while [I]0-i was at [[my]0-i house in [Perthshire]12-perthshire]3444-my house in perthshire ? ” “[1789-you] Yes , ” [she]1789-you answered . “[1789-you] It was at the close of evening , this time . [I]0-i fell asleep , or became insensible — [I]0-i can not say which . And [I]0-i saw [you]1789-you again , in a vision or a dream . ” “[1789-you] Where did [you]1789-you see [me]0-i ? ” “[1789-you] [I]0-i first saw [you]1789-you on [the bridge over [the Scotch river]55-the scotch river]1791-the bridge over the scotch river — just as [I]0-i met [you]1789-you on the evening when [you]1789-you saved [my]0-i life . After a while [the stream]2698-the stream and the landscape about it faded , and [you]1789-you faded with them , into darkness . [I]0-i waited a little , and the darkness melted away slowly . [I]0-i stood , as it seemed to [me]0-i , in a circle of starry lights ; fronting a window , with a lake behind [me]0-i , and before [me]0-i [a darkened room]1793-a darkened room . And [I]0-i looked into [the room]185-the room , and the starry light showed [you]1789-you to [me]0-i again . ” “[0-i] When did this happen ? Do [you]1789-you remember the date ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i remember that it was at the beginning of the month . The misfortunes which have since brought [me]0-i so low had not then fallen on [me]0-i ; and yet , as [I]0-i stood looking at [you]1789-you , [I]0-i had the strangest prevision of calamity that was to come . [I]0-i felt the same absolute reliance on [your]1789-you power to help [me]0-i that [I]0-i felt when [I]0-i first dreamed of [you]1789-you in [Scotland]13-scotland . And [I]0-i did the same familiar things . [I]0-i laid [my]0-i hand on [your]1789-you bosom . [I]0-i said to [you]1789-you : ‘ Remember [me]0-i . Come to [me]0-i . ’ [I]0-i even wrote — ” [She]0-i stopped , shuddering as if a sudden fear had laid its hold on [her]0-i . Seeing this , and dreading the effect of any violent agitation , [I]0-i hastened to suggest that [we]3753-we should say no more , for that day , on the subject of [her]0-i dream . “[0-i] No , ” [she]0-i answered , firmly . “[0-i] There is nothing to be gained by giving [me]0-i time . [My]0-i dream has left one horrible remembrance on [my]0-i mind . As long as [I]0-i live , [I]0-i believe [I]0-i shall tremble when [I]0-i think of what [I]0-i saw near [you]1789-you in [that darkened room]1795-that darkened room . ” [She]0-i stopped again . Was [she]0-i approaching the subject of the shrouded figure , with the black veil over its head ? Was [she]0-i about to describe [her]0-i first discovery , in the dream , of [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross ? “[0-i] Tell [me]0-i one thing first , ” [she]0-i resumed . “[0-i] Have [I]0-i been right in what [I]0-i have said to [you]1789-you , so far ? Answer [me]0-i truly ! ” “[0-i] [I]0-i was not alone . ” “[0-i] Was [the master of [the house]258-the house]3748-the master of the house with [you]1789-you ? or had [you]1789-you [some other companion]1800-some other companion ? ” It would have been worse than useless ( after what [I]0-i had now heard ) to attempt to deceive [her]237-a woman . “[0-i] [I]0-i had [another companion]1801-another companion , ” [I]1801-another companion answered . “[1801-another companion] [The person in [the room]185-the room with [me]0-i]1802-the person in the room with me was [a woman]237-a woman . ” [Her]237-a woman face showed , as [I]237-a woman spoke , that [she]237-a woman was again shaken by the terrifying recollection to which [she]237-a woman had just alluded . [I]237-a woman had , by this time , some difficulty [myself]237-a woman in preserving [my]237-a woman composure . Still , [I]237-a woman was determined not to let a word escape [me]237-a woman which could operate as a suggestion on the mind of [[my]237-a woman companion]946-my companion . “[237-a woman] Have [you]237-a woman any other question to ask [me]0-i ? ” was all [I]237-a woman said . “[237-a woman] One more , ” [she]237-a woman answered . “[237-a woman] Was there anything unusual in the dress of [[your]0-i companion]1785-your companion ? ” “[1785-your companion] Yes . [She]1785-your companion wore a long black veil , which hung over [her]1785-your companion head and face , and dropped to below [her]1785-your companion waist . ” [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt leaned back in [her]237-a woman chair , and covered [her]237-a woman eyes with [her]237-a woman hands . “[1785-your companion] [I]0-i understand [your]0-i motive for concealing from [me]0-i the presence of [that miserable woman in [the house]258-the house]1806-that miserable woman in the house , ” [she]237-a woman said . “[0-i] It is good and kind , like all [your]0-i motives ; but it is useless . While [I]0-i lay in the trance [I]0-i saw everything exactly as it was in the reality ; and [I]0-i , too , saw that frightful face ! ” Those words literally electrified [me]93-god . [My]93-god conversation of that morning with [[my]93-god mother]365-my mother instantly recurred to [my]93-god memory . [I]93-god started to [my]93-god feet . “[93-god] [Good God]93-god ! ” [I]0-i exclaimed , “[0-i] what do [you]0-i mean ? ” “[0-i] Do n’t [you]0-i understand yet ? ” [she]0-i asked in amazement on [her]0-i side . “[0-i] Must [I]0-i speak more plainly still ? When [you]0-i saw the apparition of [me]0-i , did [you]0-i see [me]0-i write ? ” “[0-i] Yes . On a letter that [the lady]2202-the lady was writing for [me]0-i . [I]0-i saw the words afterward ; the words that brought [me]0-i to [you]0-i last night : ‘ At the month ’s end , In the shadow of [Saint Paul]129-saint paul ’s . ’ ” “[2202-the lady] How did [I]0-i appear to write on the unfinished letter ? ” “[0-i] [You]0-i lifted the writing - case , on which the letter and the pen lay , off [the lady]2202-the lady ’s lap ; and , while [you]0-i wrote , [you]0-i rested the case on [her]2202-the lady shoulder . ” “[0-i] Did [you]0-i notice if the lifting of the case produced any effect on [her]2202-the lady ? ” “[0-i] [I]0-i saw no effect produced , ” [I]0-i answered . “[0-i] [She]2202-the lady remained immovable in [her]2202-the lady chair . ” “[2202-the lady] [I]0-i saw it differently in [my]0-i dream . [She]2202-the lady raised [her]2202-the lady hand — not the hand that was nearest to [you]0-i , but nearest to [me]0-i . As [I]0-i lifted the writing - case , [she]2202-the lady lifted [her]2202-the lady hand , and parted the folds of the veil from off [her]2202-the lady face — [I]0-i suppose to see more clearly . It was only for a moment ; and in that moment [I]0-i saw what the veil hid . Do n’t let [us]1810-us speak of it ! [You]0-i must have shuddered at that frightful sight in the reality , as [I]0-i shuddered at it in the dream . [You]0-i must have asked [yourself]0-i , as [I]0-i did : ‘ Is there nobody to poison [the terrible creature]1811-the terrible creature , and hide [her]1811-the terrible creature mercifully in the grave ? ’ ” At those words , [she]2202-the lady abruptly checked [herself]2202-the lady . [I]0-i could say nothing — [my]0-i face spoke for [me]0-i . Turning next to the various occasions on which [we]3841-our had met , had [we]3841-our seen enough of each other to drift into recognition on either side , in the ordinary course of talk ? [We]3841-our had met but four times in all ; once on [the bridge]2727-the bridge , once again in [Edinburgh]18-edinburgh , twice more in [London]2-london . Never ! From first to last , the course of events had borne [us]3841-our further and further away from any results that could have led even to a suspicion of the truth . [I]103-mrs. van brandt am writing prematurely of the time when the light came to [me]103-mrs. van brandt . The same day [I]103-mrs. van brandt went to [the artist]3879-the artist privately . [I]103-mrs. van brandt caused it to be inclosed in a plain gold locket , with a chain attached ; and [I]103-mrs. van brandt forwarded [my]103-mrs. van brandt gift , in the first instance , to [the one person whom [I]103-mrs. van brandt could trust to assist [me]103-mrs. van brandt in arranging for the conveyance of it to its destination]3882-the one person whom i could trust to assist me in arranging for the conveyance of it to its destination . This was [the old friend ( alluded to in these pages as “[103-mrs. van brandt] [Sir James]120-sir james ” ) who had taken [me]103-mrs. van brandt with [him]120-sir james to [Shetland]47-shetland in [the Government yacht]1429-the government yacht]3883-the old friend ( alluded to in these pages as “ sir james ” ) who had taken me with him to shetland in the government yacht . [I]103-mrs. van brandt had no reason , in writing the necessary explanations , to express [myself]103-mrs. van brandt to [Sir James]120-sir james with any reserve . It was , of course , impossible to decide whether [the doctor]364-the doctor would be able to relieve that doubt . [I]103-mrs. van brandt could only venture to suggest that the question might be guardedly put , in making the customary inquiries after the health of [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross . In those days of slow communication , [I]103-mrs. van brandt had to wait , not for days , but for weeks , before [I]103-mrs. van brandt could expect to receive [Sir James]120-sir james ’s answer . [His]120-sir james letter only reached [me]103-mrs. van brandt after an unusually long delay . For this , or for some other reason that [I]103-mrs. van brandt can not divine , [I]103-mrs. van brandt felt so strongly the foreboding of bad news that [I]103-mrs. van brandt abstained from breaking the seal in [[my]103-mrs. van brandt mother]365-my mother ’s presence . [My]103-mrs. van brandt presentiment had not deceived [me]103-mrs. van brandt . [Sir James]120-sir james ’s reply contained these words only : “[103-mrs. van brandt] The letter inclosed tells [its]1907-its own sad story , without help from [me]0-i . [I]0-i can not grieve for [her]1908-her ; but [I]0-i can feel sorry for [you]1909-you . ” The letter thus described was addressed to [Sir James]120-sir james by [the doctor at [Lerwick]44-lerwick]3892-the doctor at lerwick . [I]0-i copy it ( without comment ) in these words : “[0-i] The late stormy weather has delayed [the vessel]2622-the vessel by means of which [we]1911-we communicate with [the mainland]3556-the mainland . [I]0-i have only received [your]1909-you letter to - day . Under these melancholy circumstances , [I]0-i am , [I]0-i think , not to blame if [I]0-i hesitate to give [her]1914-the poor lady for whom the gift is intended the locket in secret ; not knowing with what associations this keepsake may be connected , or of what serious agitation it may not possibly be the cause . “ In this state of doubt [I]0-i have ventured on opening the locket , and [my]0-i hesitation is naturally increased . [I]0-i am quite ignorant of the remembrances which [[my]0-i unhappy patient]3893-my unhappy patient may connect with the portrait . [My]0-i distress of mind is great . But [I]0-i will do [my]0-i best to write intelligibly and fully of what has happened . “ [Her]1915-her sinking energies , when [I]0-i first saw [her]1915-her this morning , had rallied for the moment . [The nurse]3899-the nurse informed [me]0-i that [she]1915-her had slept during the early hours of the new day . Previously to this , there were symptoms of fever , accompanied by some slight delirium . The words that escaped [her]1915-her in this condition appear to have related mainly to [an absent person]3900-an absent person whom [she]1915-her spoke of by the name of ‘ [George]74-mr. germaine . ’ [Her]1915-her one anxiety , [I]0-i am told , was to see ‘ [George]74-mr. germaine ’ again before [she]1915-her died . “[0-i] Hearing this , it struck [me]0-i as barely possible that the portrait in the locket might be the portrait of [the absent person]1917-the absent person . [I]0-i sent [[her]1918-her nurse]1919-her nurse out of [the room]185-the room , and took [her]1918-her hand in mine .
