And then [I]0-i said , ‘ [You]1918-her know that any secret of [yours]1918-her is safe in [my]0-i keeping . Tell [me]0-i , do [you]1918-her expect to receive any little keepsake or memorial from ‘ [George]74-mr. germaine ’ ? “ It was a risk to run . The black veil which [she]1918-her always wears was over [her]1918-her face . [I]1918-her had nothing to tell [me]1918-her of the effect which [I]1918-her was producing on [her]1918-her , except the changing temperature , or the partial movement , of [her]1918-her hand , as it lay in [mine]1918-her , just under the silk coverlet of the bed . “[1918-her] [She]1918-her said nothing at first . [Her]1918-her hand turned suddenly from cold to hot , and closed with a quick pressure on [mine]0-i . [Her]1918-her breathing became oppressed . When [she]1918-her spoke , it was with difficulty . [She]1918-her told [me]0-i nothing ; [she]1918-her only put a question : “ ‘ Is [he]3901-he here ? ’ [she]1918-her asked . “[0-i] [I]0-i said , ‘ [Nobody]2485-nobody is here but [myself]0-i . ’ “ ‘ Is there a letter ? ’ “[0-i] [I]0-i said ‘ No . ’ “ [She]1918-her was silent for a while . [Her]1918-her hand turned cold ; the grasp of [her]1918-her fingers loosened . [She]1918-her spoke again : ‘ Be quick , [doctor]674-doctor ! Whatever it is , give it to [me]0-i , before [I]0-i die . ’ “[0-i] [I]0-i risked the experiment ; [I]0-i opened the locket , and put it into [her]1918-her hand . “ So far as [I]0-i could discover , [she]1918-her refrained from looking at it at first . [She]1918-her said , ‘ Turn [me]0-i in the bed , with [my]0-i face to the wall . ’ [I]0-i obeyed [her]1918-her . With [her]1918-her back turned toward [me]0-i [she]1918-her lifted [her]1918-her veil ; and then ( as [I]0-i suppose ) [she]1918-her looked at the portrait . A long , low cry — not of sorrow or pain : a cry of rapture and delight — burst from [her]1918-her . [I]0-i heard [her]1918-her kiss the portrait . Accustomed as [I]0-i am in [my]0-i profession to piteous sights and sounds , [I]0-i never remember so completely losing [my]0-i self - control as [I]0-i lost it at that moment . [I]0-i was obliged to turn away to the window . “[0-i] Hardly a minute can have passed before [I]0-i was back again at the bedside . In that brief interval [she]1923-her had changed . [Her]1923-her voice had sunk again ; it was so weak that [I]0-i could only hear what [she]1923-her said by leaning over [her]1923-her and placing [my]0-i ear close to [her]1923-her lips . “ ‘ Put it round [my]1923-her neck , ’ [she]1923-her whispered . “[1923-her] [I]0-i clasped the chain of the locket round [her]1923-her neck . [She]1923-her tried to lift [her]1923-her hand to it , but [her]1923-her strength failed [her]1923-her . “ ‘ Help [me]0-i to hide it , ’ [she]1923-her said . “[0-i] [I]0-i guided [her]1923-her hand . [She]1923-her hid the locket in [her]1923-her bosom , under the white dressing - gown which [she]1923-her wore that day . The oppression in [her]1923-her breathing increased . [I]0-i raised [her]1923-her on the pillow . The pillow was not high enough . [I]0-i rested [her]1923-her head on [my]0-i shoulder , and partially opened [her]1923-her veil . [She]1923-her was able to speak once more , feeling a momentary relief . “ ‘ Promise , ’ [she]1923-her said , ‘ that [no stranger]3903-no stranger ’s hand shall touch [me]0-i . Promise to bury [me]0-i as [I]0-i am now . ’ “[0-i] [I]0-i gave [her]1923-her [my]0-i promise . “ [Her]1923-her failing breath quickened . [She]1923-her was just able to articulate the next words : “[0-i] ‘ Cover [my]0-i face again . ’ “ [I]0-i drew the veil over [her]1923-her face . [She]1923-her rested a while in silence . Suddenly the sound of [her]1923-her laboring respiration ceased . [She]1923-her started , and raised [her]1923-her head from [my]0-i shoulder . “[0-i] ‘ Are [you]1923-her in pain ? ’ [I]0-i asked . “ ‘ [I]0-i am in heaven ! ’ [she]1923-her answered . “[0-i] [Her]1923-her head dropped back on [my]0-i breast as [she]1923-her spoke . [You]3904-your ask [me]1925-the stranger who sent her his portrait if there was any more serious reason for the persistent hiding of [her]1923-her face under the veil than the reason which [she]1923-her was accustomed to give to [the persons about [her]1923-her]3905-the persons about her . [I]1930-i put it away , and went out . The solitude of [[my]1930-i room]2363-my room forewarned [me]1930-i unendurably of the coming solitude in [my]1930-i own life . [My]1930-i interests in [this busy world]3916-this busy world were now narrowed to one object — to the care of [[my]1930-i mother]365-my mother ’s failing health . Of [the two women whose hearts had once beaten in loving sympathy with [mine]1930-i , one lay in [her]365-my mother grave]3918-the two women whose hearts had once beaten in loving sympathy with mine , one lay in her grave and the other was lost to [me]1930-i in [a foreign land]3919-a foreign land . On the drive by [the sea]3277-the sea [I]1930-i met [[my]1930-i mother]365-my mother , in [her]365-my mother little pony - chaise , moving slowly under the mild wintry sunshine . [I]1930-i dismissed [the man who was in attendance on [her]365-my mother]3922-the man who was in attendance on her , and walked by the side of the chaise , with the reins in [my]1930-i hand . [We]3923-we chatted quietly on trivial subjects . [I]1930-i closed [my]1930-i eyes to the dreary future that was before [me]1930-i , and tried , in the intervals of the heart - ache , to live resignedly in the passing hour . The last parting is over . Prolonged by [my]1930-i care , the days of [[my]1930-i mother]365-my mother ’s life have come to their end . [She]365-my mother has died in [my]1930-i arms : [her]365-my mother last words have been spoken to [me]1930-i , [her]365-my mother last look on [earth]496-earth has been [mine]1930-i . [I]1930-i am now , in the saddest and plainest meaning of the words , alone in [the world]287-the world . [[My]1930-i house]576-my house is let ; [I]1930-i am staying at [a hotel]702-a hotel . [The physician who first warned [me]1930-i of the critical state of [[my]1930-i mother]365-my mother ’s health]3937-the physician who first warned me of the critical state of my mother ’s health is anxious to hear what [I]1930-i can tell [him]3937-the physician who first warned me of the critical state of my mother ’s health of [her]365-my mother last moments . The conversation turns next on topics of little interest to [me]1930-i : [my]1930-i mind rests after the effort that it has made ; [my]1930-i observation is left free to exert itself as usual . Over and over again [I]1930-i notice that [he]3937-the physician who first warned me of the critical state of my mother ’s health contrives to divert the conversation from general topics , and to lure [me]1930-i into talking of [myself]1930-i ; and , stranger still ( unless [I]1930-i am quite mistaken ) , [Sir James]120-sir james understands and encourages [him]3937-the physician who first warned me of the critical state of my mother ’s health . Under various pretenses [I]1930-i am questioned about what [I]1930-i have suffered in the past , and what plans of life [I]1930-i have formed for the future . [I]1930-i am asked if [I]1930-i believe in occult spiritual sympathies , and in ghostly apparitions of dead or [distant persons]3944-distant persons . [I]1930-i am dexterously led into hinting that [my]1930-i views on this difficult and debatable question are in some degree influenced by experiences of [my]1930-i own . Hints , however , are not enough to satisfy [the doctor]364-the doctor ’s innocent curiosity ; [he]3937-the physician who first warned me of the critical state of my mother ’s health tries to induce [me]1930-i to relate in detail what [I]1930-i have [myself]1930-i seen and felt . But by this time [I]1930-i am on [my]1930-i guard ; [I]1930-i make excuses ; [I]1930-i steadily abstain from taking [[my]1930-i friend]2203-my friend into [my]1930-i confidence . It is more and more plain to [me]1930-i that [I]1930-i am being made the subject of an experiment , in which [Sir James]120-sir james and [the physician]3947-the physician are equally interested . Outwardly assuming to be guiltless of any suspicion of what is going on , [I]1930-i inwardly determine to discover the true motive for [the doctor]364-the doctor ’s presence that evening , and for the part that [Sir James]120-sir james has taken in inviting [him]364-the doctor to be [[my]1930-i guest]3341-my guest . Events favor [my]1930-i purpose soon after the dessert has been placed on the table . [The waiter]3950-the waiter enters [the room]185-the room with a letter for [me]1930-i , and announces that [the bearer]3952-the bearer waits to know if there is any answer . [I]1930-i have only to stand under the ventilator , and every word of the conversation between [Sir James]120-sir james and [the physician]3947-the physician reaches [my]1930-i ears . “[1930-i] Then [you]1930-i think [I]0-i am right ? ” are the first words [I]1930-i hear , in [Sir James]120-sir james ’s voice . “[1930-i] Quite right , ” [the doctor]364-the doctor answers . “[1930-i] [I]0-i have done [my]0-i best to make [him]1931-his change [his]1931-his dull way of life , ” [Sir James]120-sir james proceeds . “[0-i] [I]0-i have asked [him]1931-his to pay a visit to [[my]0-i house in [Scotland]13-scotland]1932-my house in scotland ; [I]0-i have proposed traveling with [him]1931-his on [the Continent]29-the continent ; [I]0-i have offered to take [him]1931-his with [me]0-i on [my]0-i next voyage in [the yacht]1933-the yacht . [He]1931-his has but one answer — [he]1931-his simply says No to everything that [I]0-i can suggest . [You]1934-you have heard from [his]1931-his own lips that [he]1931-his has no definite plans for the future . What is to become of [him]1931-his ? What had [we]1935-we better do ? ” “[1934-you] It is not easy to say , ” [I]1934-you hear [the physician]3947-the physician reply . “[1934-you] To speak plainly , [the man]2308-the man ’s nervous system is seriously deranged . [I]0-i noticed something strange in [him]1931-his when [he]1931-his first came to consult [me]0-i about [[his]1931-his mother]645-his mother ’s health . The mischief has not been caused entirely by the affliction of [her]645-his mother death . In [my]0-i belief , [his]1931-his mind has been — what shall [I]0-i say?—unhinged , for some time past . [He]1931-his is [a very reserved person]1938-a very reserved person . [I]0-i suspect [he]1931-his has been oppressed by anxieties which [he]1931-his has kept secret from [every one]1939-every one . At [his]1931-his age , the unacknowledged troubles of life are generally troubles caused by [women]420-women . It is in [his]1931-his temperament to take the romantic view of love ; and [some matter - of - fact woman of the present day]1941-some matter - of - fact woman of the present day may have bitterly disappointed [him]1931-his . Whatever may be the cause , the effect is plain — [his]1931-his nerves have broken down , and [his]1931-his brain is necessarily affected by whatever affects [his]1931-his nerves . [I]0-i have known men in [his]1931-his condition who have ended badly . [He]1931-his may drift into insane delusions , if [his]1931-his present course of life is not altered . Did [you]0-i hear what [he]1931-his said when [we]1942-we talked about ghosts ? ” “[1931-his] Sheer nonsense ! ” [Sir James]120-sir james remarks . “[1931-his] Sheer delusion would be the more correct form of expression , ” [the doctor]364-the doctor rejoins . “[1931-his] And other delusions may grow out of it at any moment . ” “[1931-his] What is to be done ? ” persists [Sir James]120-sir james . “[1931-his] [I]0-i may really say for [myself]0-i , [doctor]674-doctor , that [I]0-i feel a fatherly interest in [the poor fellow]1944-the poor fellow . [[His]1944-the poor fellow mother]645-his mother was [one of [[my]0-i oldest and dearest friends]1947-my oldest and dearest friends]1946-one of my oldest and dearest friends , and [he]1944-the poor fellow has inherited many of [her]645-his mother engaging and endearing qualities . [I]0-i hope [you]674-doctor do n’t think the case is bad enough to be a case for restraint ? ” “[674-doctor] Certainly not — as yet , ” answers [the doctor]364-the doctor . “[674-doctor] So far there is no positive brain disease ; and there is accordingly no sort of reason for placing [him]1944-the poor fellow under restraint . It is essentially a difficult and a doubtful case . Have [him]1944-the poor fellow privately looked after by [a competent person]1948-a competent person , and thwart [him]1944-the poor fellow in nothing , if [you]674-doctor can possibly help it . The merest trifle may excite [his]1944-the poor fellow suspicions ; and if that happens , [we]1949-we lose all control over [him]1944-the poor fellow . ” “[674-doctor] [You]674-doctor do n’t think [he]1944-the poor fellow suspects [us]1949-we already , do [you]674-doctor , [doctor]674-doctor ? ” “[674-doctor] [I]0-i hope not . [I]0-i saw [him]1944-the poor fellow once or twice look at [me]0-i very strangely ; and [he]1944-the poor fellow has certainly been a long time out of [the room]185-the room . ” Hearing this , [I]1944-the poor fellow wait to hear no more . [I]1944-the poor fellow return to [the sitting - room]1040-the sitting - room ( by way of [the corridor]3967-the corridor ) and resume [my]1944-the poor fellow place at the table . The indignation that [I]1944-the poor fellow feel — naturally enough , [I]1944-the poor fellow think , under the circumstances — makes a good actor of [me]1944-the poor fellow for once in [my]1944-the poor fellow life . [I]1944-the poor fellow invent the necessary excuse for [my]1944-the poor fellow long absence , and take [my]1944-the poor fellow part in the conversation , keeping the strictest guard on every word that escapes [me]1944-the poor fellow , without betraying any appearance of restraint in [my]1944-the poor fellow manner . Early in the evening [the doctor]364-the doctor leaves [us]3969-we to go to a scientific meeting . For half an hour or more [Sir James]120-sir james remains with [me]1944-the poor fellow . [Sir James]120-sir james is delighted . [We]3969-we shake hands cordially , and wish [each other]354-each other good - night . At last [I]1944-the poor fellow am left alone . [My]1944-the poor fellow resolution as to [my]1944-the poor fellow next course of proceeding is formed without a moment ’s hesitation . [I]1944-the poor fellow determine to leave [the hotel]156-the hotel privately the next morning before [Sir James]120-sir james is out of [[his]120-sir james bedroom]1214-his bedroom . To what destination [I]1944-the poor fellow am to betake [myself]1944-the poor fellow is naturally the next question that arises , and this also [I]1944-the poor fellow easily decide . During the last days of [[my]1944-the poor fellow mother]365-my mother ’s life [we]3969-we spoke together frequently of the happy past days when [we]3969-we were living together on [the banks of [the Greenwater lake]3977-the greenwater lake]3976-the banks of the greenwater lake . The longing thus inspired to look once more at the old scenes , to live for a while again among [the old associations]3978-the old associations , has grown on [me]1944-the poor fellow since [[my]1944-the poor fellow mother]365-my mother ’s death . [I]1944-the poor fellow have , happily for [myself]1944-the poor fellow , not spoken of this feeling to [Sir James]120-sir james or to [any other person]3980-any other person . To [the old home in [Suffolk]6-suffolk]3982-the old home in suffolk [I]1944-the poor fellow resolve to go the next morning . [I]1944-the poor fellow enter [[my]1944-the poor fellow bedroom]3992-my bedroom next , and pack a traveling - bag with the few things that [I]1944-the poor fellow can carry with [me]1944-the poor fellow . For a while [I]1944-the poor fellow sit idly looking at the device on the flag — the white dove embroidered on the green ground , with the golden olive - branch in its beak . The innocent love - story of [my]1944-the poor fellow early life returns to [my]1944-the poor fellow memory , and shows [me]1944-the poor fellow in horrible contrast the life that [I]1944-the poor fellow am leading now . [I]1944-the poor fellow fold up the flag and place it carefully in [my]1944-the poor fellow traveling - bag . This done , all is done . [I]1944-the poor fellow may rest till the morning comes . No ! [I]1944-the poor fellow lie down on [my]1944-the poor fellow bed , and [I]1944-the poor fellow discover that there is no rest for [me]1944-the poor fellow that night . Now that [I]1944-the poor fellow have no occupation to keep [my]1944-the poor fellow energies employed , now that [my]1944-the poor fellow first sense of triumph in the discomfiture of [the friends who have plotted against [me]1944-the poor fellow]3996-the friends who have plotted against me has had time to subside , [my]1944-the poor fellow mind reverts to the conversation that [I]1944-the poor fellow have overheard , and considers it from a new point of view . For the first time , the terrible question confronts [me]1944-the poor fellow : [The doctor]364-the doctor ’s opinion on [my]1944-the poor fellow case has been given very positively . How do [I]1944-the poor fellow know that [the doctor]364-the doctor is not right ? [This famous physician]3999-this famous physician has risen to the head of [his]3999-this famous physician profession entirely by [his]3999-this famous physician own abilities . [He]3999-this famous physician is one of [the medical men who succeed by means of an ingratiating manner and the dexterous handling of good opportunities]4000-the medical men who succeed by means of an ingratiating manner and the dexterous handling of good opportunities . Is such [a man]2326-a man as this likely to be mistaken about [me]1944-the poor fellow ? Is it not far more probable that [I]1944-the poor fellow am mistaken in [my]1944-the poor fellow judgment of [myself]1944-the poor fellow ? When [I]1944-the poor fellow look back over the past years , am [I]1944-the poor fellow quite sure that the strange events which [I]1944-the poor fellow recall may not , in certain cases , be the visionary product of [my]1944-the poor fellow own disordered brain — realities to [me]1944-the poor fellow , and to [no one else]4003-no one else ? What are the dreams of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt ? What are the ghostly apparitions of [her]103-mrs. van brandt which [I]1944-the poor fellow believe [myself]1944-the poor fellow to have seen ? Delusions which have been the stealthy growth of years ? delusions which are leading [me]1944-the poor fellow , by slow degrees , nearer and nearer to madness in the end ? Is it insane suspicion which has made [me]1944-the poor fellow so angry with [the good friends who have been trying to save [my]1944-the poor fellow reason]4004-the good friends who have been trying to save my reason ? Is it insane terror which sets [me]1944-the poor fellow on escaping from [the hotel]156-the hotel like [a criminal escaping from prison]4006-a criminal escaping from prison ? These are the questions which torment [me]1944-the poor fellow when [I]1944-the poor fellow am alone in the dead of night . [My]1944-the poor fellow bed becomes a place of unendurable torture . [I]1944-the poor fellow rise and dress [myself]1944-the poor fellow , and wait for the daylight , looking through [my]1944-the poor fellow open window into [the street]960-the street . Why should [I]1944-the poor fellow wait in [the room that is still haunted by [my]1944-the poor fellow horrible doubts of the night]4008-the room that is still haunted by my horrible doubts of the night ? [The night - porter]4010-the night - porter at [the hotel]156-the hotel is slumbering in [his]4010-the night - porter chair . [He]4010-the night - porter wakes as [I]1944-the poor fellow pass [him]4010-the night - porter ; and ( God help [me]1944-the poor fellow ! ) [he]4010-the night - porter too looks as if [he]4010-the night - porter thought [I]1944-the poor fellow was mad . “[1944-the poor fellow] Going to leave [us]1952-us already , [sir]2230-sir ? ” [he]4010-the night - porter says , looking at the bag in [my]1954-i hand . Mad or sane , [I]1954-i am ready with [my]1954-i reply . [I]1954-i tell [him]4010-the night - porter [I]1954-i am going out for a day in [the country]671-the country , and to make it a long day , [I]1954-i must start early . [The man]2308-the man still stares at [me]1954-i . [He]2308-the man asks if [he]2308-the man shall find some one to carry [my]1954-i bag . [I]1954-i decline to let [anybody be disturbed]4014-anybody be disturbed . [He]2308-the man inquires if [I]1954-i have any messages to leave for [[my]1954-i friend]2203-my friend . Upon this [he]2308-the man draws the bolts and opens the door . To the last [he]2308-the man looks at [me]1954-i as if [he]2308-the man thought [I]1954-i was mad . Was [he]2308-the man right or wrong ? Who can answer for [himself]2308-the man ? How can [I]1954-i tell ? [MY]1954-i spirits rose as [I]1954-i walked through [the bright empty streets]4018-the bright empty streets , and breathed the fresh morning air . Taking [my]1954-i way eastward through [the great city]3681-the great city , [I]1954-i stopped at [the first office that [I]1954-i passed]4020-the first office that i passed , and secured [[my]1954-i place]4021-my place by [the early coach to [Ipswich]58-ipswich]4022-the early coach to ipswich . Thence [I]1954-i traveled with post - horses to [the market - town which was nearest to [Greenwater Broad]5-greenwater broad]4023-the market - town which was nearest to greenwater broad . A walk of a few miles in the cool evening brought [me]1954-i , through [well - remembered by - roads]4024-well - remembered by - roads , to [[our]4025-our old house]4026-our old house . By the last rays of the setting sun [I]1954-i looked at the familiar row of windows in front , and saw that the shutters were all closed . [Not a living creature]903-not a living creature was visible anywhere . Not even a dog barked as [I]1954-i rang the great bell at the door . [The place]2384-the place was deserted ; [the house]258-the house was shut up . After a long delay , [I]1954-i heard heavy footsteps in [the hall]3813-the hall . [An old man]658-an old man opened the door . Changed as [he]658-an old man was , [I]1954-i remembered [him]658-an old man as [one of [[our]4025-our tenants]4033-our tenants in the by - gone time]4032-one of our tenants in the by - gone time . To [his]658-an old man astonishment , [I]1954-i greeted [him]658-an old man by [his]658-an old man name . On [his]658-an old man side , [he]658-an old man tried hard to recognize [me]1954-i , and tried in vain . No doubt [I]1954-i was the more sadly changed of the two : [I]1954-i was obliged to introduce [myself]1954-i . [The poor fellow]1944-the poor fellow ’s withered face brightened slowly and timidly , as if [he]658-an old man were half incapable , half afraid , of indulging in the unaccustomed luxury of a smile . In [his]658-an old man confusion [he]658-an old man bid [me]1954-i welcome [home]2233-home ag ain , as if [the house]258-the house had been [mine]1954-i . Taking [me]1954-i into [the little back - room which [he]658-an old man inhabited]4037-the little back - room which he inhabited , [the old man]4038-the old man gave [me]1954-i all [he]658-an old man had to offer — a supper of bacon and eggs and a glass of home - brewed beer . [He]658-an old man was evidently puzzled to understand [me]1954-i when [I]1954-i informed [him]658-an old man that the only object of [my]1954-i visit was to look once more at the familiar scenes round [[my]1954-i old home]2443-my old home . But [he]658-an old man willingly placed [his]658-an old man services at [my]1954-i disposal ; and [he]658-an old man engaged to do [his]658-an old man best , if [I]1954-i wished it , to make [me]1954-i up a bed for the night . [The house]258-the house had been closed and the establishment of [servants]4041-servants had been dismissed for more than a year past . A passion for horse - racing , developed late in life , had ruined [the rich retired tradesman who had purchased [the estate]4043-the estate at the time of [our]4044-our family troubles]4042-the rich retired tradesman who had purchased the estate at the time of our family troubles . [He]658-an old man had gone abroad with [[his]658-an old man wife]215-his wife to live on the little income that had been saved from the wreck of [his]658-an old man fortune ; and [he]658-an old man had left [the house]258-the house and lands in such a state of neglect that [no new purchaser]4047-no new purchaser had thus far been found to take [them]4048-them . [[My]1954-i old friend]4049-my old friend , “[1954-i] now past [his]1954-i work , ” had been put in charge of [the place]2384-the place . As for [[Dermody]85-mary ’s cottage]2379-dermody ’s cottage , [it]2379-dermody ’s cottage was empty , like [the house]258-the house . [I]1954-i was at perfect liberty to look over [it]2379-dermody ’s cottage if [I]1954-i liked . There was the key of the door on the bunch with the others ; and here was [the old man]4038-the old man , with [his]4038-the old man old hat on [his]4038-the old man head , ready to accompany [me]1954-i wherever [I]1954-i pleased to go . [I]1954-i declined to trouble [him]4038-the old man to accompany [me]1954-i or to make up a bed in [the lonely house]4054-the lonely house . The night was fine , the moon was rising . [I]1954-i had supped ; [I]1954-i had rested . When [I]1954-i had seen what [I]1954-i wanted to see , [I]1954-i could easily walk back to [the market - town]4055-the market - town and sleep at [the inn]2784-the inn . Taking the key in [my]1954-i hand , [I]1954-i set forth alone on the way through [the grounds which led to [[Dermody]85-mary ’s cottage]2379-dermody ’s cottage]4057-the grounds which led to dermody ’s cottage . Again [I]1954-i followed the woodland paths along which [I]1954-i had once idled so happily with [[my]1954-i little [Mary]85-mary]299-my little mary . At every step [I]1954-i saw something that reminded [me]1954-i of [her]85-mary . Here was the rustic bench on which [we]4060-we had sat together under the shadow of the old cedar - tree , and vowed to be constant to each other to the end of [our]4060-we lives . There was [the bright little water spring , from which [we]4060-we drank when [we]4060-we were weary and thirsty in sultry summer days , still bubbling its way downward to [the lake]289-the lake]4061-the bright little water spring , from which we drank when we were weary and thirsty in sultry summer days , still bubbling its way downward to the lake as cheerily as ever . As [I]1954-i listened to the companionable murmur of [the stream]2698-the stream , [I]1954-i almost expected to see [her]85-mary again , in [her]85-mary simple white frock and straw hat , singing to the music of the rivulet , and freshening [her]85-mary nosegay of wild flowers by dipping it in the cool water . A few steps further on and [I]1954-i reached [a clearing in the wood]4064-a clearing in the wood and stood on [a little promontory of rising ground which commanded the prettiest view of [Greenwater lake]4066-greenwater lake]4065-a little promontory of rising ground which commanded the prettiest view of greenwater lake . A platform of wood was built out from the bank , to be used for bathing by [good swimmers who were not afraid of a plunge into deep water]4067-good swimmers who were not afraid of a plunge into deep water . [I]1954-i stood on [the platform]4068-the platform and looked round [me]1954-i . The trees that fringed [the shore]2463-the shore on either hand murmured their sweet sylvan music in the night air ; the moonlight trembled softly on the rippling water . Away on [my]1954-i right hand [I]1954-i could just see [the old wooden shed that once sheltered [[my]1954-i boat]392-my boat]4070-the old wooden shed that once sheltered my boat in the days when [Mary]85-mary went sailing with [me]1954-i and worked the green flag . On [my]1954-i left was the wooden paling that followed the curves of [the winding creek]4072-the winding creek , and beyond [it]4073-it rose the brown arches of [the decoy for wild fowl]4074-the decoy for wild fowl , now falling to ruin for want of use . Guided by the radiant moonlight , [I]1954-i could see the very spot on which [Mary]85-mary and [I]1954-i had stood to watch the snaring of the ducks . Through the hole in the paling before which the decoy - dog had shown [himself]4074-the decoy for wild fowl , at [Dermody]85-mary ’s signal , a water - rat now passed , like a little black shadow on the bright ground , and was lost in [the waters of [the lake]289-the lake]288-the waters of the lake . Look where [I]1954-i might , the happy by - gone time looked back in mockery , and the voices of the past came to [me]1954-i with [their]4077-their burden of reproach : See what [your]4078-your life was once ! Is [your]4078-your life worth living now ? [I]1954-i picked up a stone and threw it into [the lake]289-the lake . [I]1954-i watched the circling ripples round the place at which it had sunk . [I]1954-i wondered if [a practiced swimmer like [myself]1954-i]4080-a practiced swimmer like myself had ever tried to commit suicide by drowning , and had been so resolute to die that [he]4080-a practiced swimmer like myself had resisted the temptation to let [his]4080-a practiced swimmer like myself own skill keep [him]4080-a practiced swimmer like myself from sinking . Something in [the lake]289-the lake [itself]289-the lake , or something in connection with the thought that it had put into [my]1954-i mind , revolted [me]1954-i . [I]1954-i turned [my]1954-i back suddenly on the lonely view , and took the path through the wood which led to [[the bailiff]320-the bailiff ’s cottage]2857-the bailiff ’s cottage . Opening the door with [my]1954-i key , [I]1954-i groped [my]1954-i way into [the well - remembered parlor]4084-the well - remembered parlor ; and , unbarring the window - shutters , [I]1954-i let in the light of the moon . With a heavy heart [I]1954-i looked round [me]1954-i . The old furniture — renewed , perhaps , in one or two places — asserted its mute claim to [my]1954-i recognition in every part of [the room]185-the room . The tender moonlight streamed slanting into the corner in which [Mary]85-mary and [I]1954-i used to nestle together while [Dame Dermody]88-dame dermody was at the window reading [her]88-dame dermody mystic books . Overshadowed by the obscurity in the opposite corner , [I]1954-i discovered the high - backed arm - chair of carved wood in which [the Sibyl of [the cottage]363-the cottage]4086-the sibyl of the cottage sat on the memorable day when [she]88-dame dermody warned [us]4088-us of [our]4088-us coming separation , and gave [us]4088-us [her]88-dame dermody blessing for the last time . Looking next round the walls of [the room]185-the room , [I]1954-i recognized [old friends]4090-old friends wherever [my]1954-i eyes happened to rest — the gaudily colored prints ; the framed pictures in fine needle - work , which [we]4088-us thought wonderful efforts of art ; the old circular mirror to which [I]1954-i used to lift [Mary]85-mary when [she]85-mary wanted “[1954-i] to see [her]1955-i face in the glass . ” Whenever the moonlight penetrated there , it showed [me]1955-i some familiar object that recalled [my]1955-i happiest days . Again the by - gone time looked back in mockery . Again the voices of the past came to [me]1955-i with [their]4091-their burden of reproach : See what [your]1955-i life was once ! Is [your]1955-i life worth living now ? [I]1955-i sat down at the window , where [I]1955-i could just discover , here and there between the trees , the glimmer of [the waters of [the lake]289-the lake]288-the waters of the lake . [I]1955-i thought to [myself]1955-i : “[1955-i] Thus far [my]0-i mortal journey has brought [me]0-i . Why not end it here ? ” Who would grieve for [me]1954-i if [my]1954-i death were reported to - morrow ? Of [all living men]4094-all living men , [I]1954-i had perhaps the smallest number of [friends]3384-friends , the fewest duties to perform toward [others]2521-others , the least reason to hesitate at leaving [a world which had no place in [it]4097-a world which had no place in it for my ambition for [my]1954-i ambition]4097-a world which had no place in it for my ambition , [no creature in it for [my]1954-i love]4098-no creature in it for my love . Besides , what necessity was there for letting it be known that [my]1954-i death was a death of [my]1954-i own seeking ? It could easily be left to represent itself as a death by accident . On that fine summer night , and after a long day of traveling , might [I]1954-i not naturally take a bath in the cool water before [I]1954-i went to bed ? And , practiced as [I]1954-i was in the exercise of swimming , might it not nevertheless be [my]1954-i misfortune to be attacked by cramp ? On [the lonely shores of [Greenwater]59-greenwater]4099-the lonely shores of greenwater Broad the cry of [a drowning man]4100-a drowning man would bring no help at night . The fatal accident would explain itself . There was literally but one difficulty in the way — the difficulty which had already occurred to [my]1954-i mind . Could [I]1954-i sufficiently master the animal instinct of self - preservation to deliberately let [myself]1954-i sink at the first plunge ? The atmosphere in [the room]185-the room felt close and heavy . [I]1954-i went out , and walked to and fro — now in the shadow , and now in the moonlight — under the trees before [the cottage]363-the cottage door . Of the moral objections to suicide , [not one]4103-not one had any influence over [me]1954-i now . [I]1954-i , [who had once found it impossible to excuse , impossible even to understand]4104-who had once found it impossible to excuse , impossible even to understand , the despair which had driven [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt to attempt self - destruction — [I]1954-i now contemplated with composure the very act which had horrified [me]1954-i when [I]1954-i saw it committed by [another person]3043-another person . Well may [we]4106-we hesitate to condemn the frailties of [our]4106-we fellow - creatures , for the one unanswerable reason that [we]4106-we can never feel sure how soon similar temptations may not lead [us]4106-we to be guilty of the same frailties [ourselves]4106-we . Looking back at the events of the night , [I]1954-i can recall but one consideration that stayed [my]1954-i feet on the fatal path which led back to [the lake]289-the lake . [I]1954-i still doubted whether it would be possible for such a swimmer as [I]1954-i was to drown [himself]3043-another person . This was all that troubled [my]1954-i mind . For the rest , [my]1954-i will was made , and [I]1954-i had few other affairs which remained unsettled . No lingering hope was left in [me]1954-i of a reunion in the future with [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt . [She]103-mrs. van brandt had never written to [me]1954-i again ; [I]1954-i had ( forgiven ) [her]103-mrs. van brandt for having forgotten [me]1954-i . [My]1954-i thoughts of [her]103-mrs. van brandt and of [others]2521-others were the forbearing thoughts of [a man whose mind was withdrawn already from [the world]287-the world , whose views were narrowing fast to the one idea of [his]3043-another person own death]4109-a man whose mind was withdrawn already from the world , whose views were narrowing fast to the one idea of his own death . [I]1954-i grew weary of walking up and down . The loneliness of [the place]2384-the place began to oppress [me]1954-i . The sense of [my]1954-i own indecision irritated [my]1954-i nerves . After a long look at [the lake]289-the lake through the trees , [I]1954-i came to a positive conclusion at last . [I]1954-i determined to try if [a good swimmer]4113-a good swimmer could drown [himself]4113-a good swimmer . RETURNING to [the cottage parlor]2491-the cottage parlor , [I]1954-i took a chair by the window and opened [my]1954-i pocket - book at a blank page . [I]1954-i had certain directions to give to [[my]1954-i representatives]4115-my representatives , which might spare [them]4115-my representatives some trouble and uncertainty in the event of [my]1954-i death . Disguising [my]1954-i last instructions under the commonplace heading of “[1954-i] Memoranda on [my]0-i return to [London]2-london , ” [I]0-i began to write . [I]0-i had filled one page of the pocket - book , and had just turned to the next , when [I]0-i became conscious of a difficulty in fixing [my]0-i attention on the subject that was before it . [I]0-i was at once reminded of the similar difficulty which [I]0-i felt in [Shetland]47-shetland , when [I]0-i had tried vainly to arrange the composition of the letter to [[my]0-i mother]365-my mother which [Miss Dunross]127-miss dunross was to write . By way of completing the parallel , [my]0-i thoughts wandered now , as they had wandered then , to [my]0-i latest remembrance of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt . In a minute or two [I]0-i began to feel once more the strange physical sensations which [I]0-i had first experienced in [the garden at [Mr. Dunross]122-mr. dunross ’s house]4117-the garden at mr. dunross ’s house . The same mysterious trembling shuddered through [me]0-i from head to foot . [I]0-i looked about [me]0-i again , with no distinct consciousness of what the objects were on which [my]0-i eyes rested . [My]0-i nerves trembled , on that lovely summer night , as if there had been an electric disturbance in the atmosphere and a storm coming . [I]0-i laid [my]0-i pocket - book and pencil on the table , and rose to go out again under the trees . Even the trifling effort to cross [the room]185-the room was an effort made in vain . [I]0-i stood rooted to the spot , with [my]0-i face turned toward the moonlight streaming in at the open door . An interval passed , and as [I]0-i still looked out through the door , [I]0-i became aware of something moving far down among the trees that fringed [the shore of [the lake]289-the lake]4119-the shore of the lake . The first impression produced on [me]0-i was of two gray shadows winding their way slowly toward [me]0-i between the trunks of the trees . By fine degrees the shadows assumed a more and more marked outline , until [they]4121-they presented [themselves]4121-they in the likeness of [two robed figures]4122-two robed figures , one taller than the other . While [they]4121-they glided nearer and nearer , [their]4121-they gray obscurity of hue melted away . [They]4121-they brightened softly with an inner light of [their]4121-they own as [they]4121-they slowly approached the open space before the door . For the third time [I]0-i stood in the ghostly presence of [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt ; and with [her]103-mrs. van brandt , holding [her]103-mrs. van brandt hand , [I]0-i beheld a second apparition never before revealed to [me]0-i , the apparition of [[her]103-mrs. van brandt child]3247-her child . Hand - in - hand , shining in their unearthly brightness through the bright moonlight itself , [the two]262-the two stood before [me]0-i . [The mother]1743-the mother ’s face looked at [me]0-i once more with the sorrowful and pleading eyes which [I]0-i remembered so well . But the face of [the child]2711-the child was innocently radiant with an angelic smile . [I]0-i waited in unutterable expectation for the word that was to be spoken , for the movement that was to come . The movement came first . [The child]2711-the child released its hold on [the mother]1743-the mother ’s hand , and floating slowly upward , remained poised in midair — a softly glowing presence shining out of the dark background of the trees . [The mother]1743-the mother glided into [the room]185-the room , and stopped at the table on which [I]0-i had laid [my]0-i pocket - book and pencil when [I]0-i could no longer write . As before , [she]1743-the mother took the pencil and wrote on the blank page . As before , [she]1743-the mother beckoned to [me]0-i to step nearer to [her]1743-the mother . [I]0-i approached [her]1743-the mother outstretched hand , and felt once more the mysterious rapture of [her]1743-the mother touch on [my]0-i bosom , and heard once more [her]1743-the mother low , melodious tones repeating the words : “[0-i] Remember [me]0-i . Come to [me]0-i . ” [Her]1743-the mother hand dropped from [my]103-mrs. van brandt bosom . The pale light which revealed [her]1743-the mother to [me]103-mrs. van brandt quivered , sunk , vanished . [She]1743-the mother had spoken . [She]1743-the mother had gone . [I]103-mrs. van brandt drew to [me]103-mrs. van brandt the open pocket - book . And this time [I]103-mrs. van brandt saw , in the writing of the ghostly hand , these words only : [I]103-mrs. van brandt looked out again at [the lonely night landscape]4131-the lonely night landscape . There , in mid - air , shining softly out of the dark background of the trees , still hovered the starry apparition of [the child]2711-the child . Advancing without conscious will of [my]103-mrs. van brandt own , [I]103-mrs. van brandt crossed the threshold of the door . The softly glowing vision of [the child]2711-the child moved away before [me]103-mrs. van brandt among the trees . [I]103-mrs. van brandt followed , like [a man spellbound]4134-a man spellbound . [The apparition , floating slowly onward]4135-the apparition , floating slowly onward , led [me]103-mrs. van brandt out of [the wood]4136-the wood , and past [[my]103-mrs. van brandt old home]2443-my old home , back to [the lonely by - road along which [I]103-mrs. van brandt had walked from [the market - town]4055-the market - town to [the house]258-the house]4138-the lonely by - road along which i had walked from the market - town to the house . From time to time , as [we]4141-we two went on [our]4141-we way , [the bright figure of the child]4142-the bright figure of the child paused , hovering low in the cloudless sky . [Its]4142-the bright figure of the child radiant face looked down smiling on [me]103-mrs. van brandt ; it beckoned with [its]4142-the bright figure of the child little hand , and floated on again , leading [me]103-mrs. van brandt as [the Star]4143-the star led the Eastern sages in the olden time . [I]103-mrs. van brandt reached [the town]1544-the town . The airy figure of [the child]2711-the child paused , hovering over the house at which [I]103-mrs. van brandt had left [[my]103-mrs. van brandt traveling - carriage]4146-my traveling - carriage in the evening . [I]103-mrs. van brandt ordered the horses to be harnessed again for another journey . [The postilion]4147-the postilion waited for [his]4147-the postilion further directions . Changing the horses stage by stage , [I]103-mrs. van brandt went on till the night ended — went on till the sun rose in the eastern heaven . And still , whether it was dark or whether it was light , the figure of [the child]2711-the child floated on before [me]103-mrs. van brandt in its changeless and mystic light . Mile after mile , [it]2711-the child still led the way southward , till [we]4153-we left [the country]671-the country behind [us]4153-we , and passing through the din and turmoil of [the great city]3681-the great city , stopped under the shadow of [the ancient Tower]4158-the ancient tower , within view of [the river that runs by [it]4158-the ancient tower]4159-the river that runs by it . [I]103-mrs. van brandt looked upward again . [The child]2711-the child ’s hand pointed toward [the river]2721-the river . Floating on before [me]103-mrs. van brandt , [the child]2711-the child led the way to [a wharf]4167-a wharf crowded with [travelers]4168-travelers and [their]4168-travelers luggage . [I]103-mrs. van brandt looked up . [The child]2711-the child looked back at [me]103-mrs. van brandt with [its]2711-the child radiant smile , and pointed eastward down [the river]2721-the river toward [the distant sea]4175-the distant sea . While [my]103-mrs. van brandt eyes were still fixed on the softly glowing figure , [I]103-mrs. van brandt saw it fade away upward and upward into the higher light , as the lark vanishes upward and upward in the morning sky . [I]103-mrs. van brandt was alone again with [[my]103-mrs. van brandt earthly fellow - beings]4176-my earthly fellow - beings — left with no clew to guide [me]103-mrs. van brandt but the remembrance of [the child]2711-the child ’s hand pointing eastward to [the distant sea]4175-the distant sea . [She]103-mrs. van brandt had need of [me]103-mrs. van brandt again ; [she]103-mrs. van brandt had claimed [me]103-mrs. van brandt again . Where the visionary hand of [the child]2711-the child had pointed , thither [I]103-mrs. van brandt was destined to go . Abroad or at [home]2233-home , it mattered nothing : when [I]103-mrs. van brandt next set [my]103-mrs. van brandt foot on [the land]339-the land , [I]103-mrs. van brandt should be further directed on the journey which lay before [me]103-mrs. van brandt . [I]103-mrs. van brandt believed this as firmly as [I]103-mrs. van brandt believed that [I]103-mrs. van brandt had been guided , thus far , by the vision of [the child]2711-the child . For two nights [I]103-mrs. van brandt had not slept — [my]103-mrs. van brandt weariness overpowered [me]103-mrs. van brandt . [I]103-mrs. van brandt descended to [the cabin]4187-the cabin , and found [an unoccupied corner in which [I]103-mrs. van brandt could lie down to rest]4188-an unoccupied corner in which i could lie down to rest . When [I]103-mrs. van brandt awoke , it was night already , and [the vessel]2622-the vessel was at [sea]625-sea . [I]103-mrs. van brandt went on [deck]862-deck to breathe the fresh air . Before long the sensation of drowsiness returned ; [I]103-mrs. van brandt slept again for hours together . [[My]103-mrs. van brandt friend]2203-my friend , [the physician]3947-the physician , would no doubt have attributed this prolonged need of repose to the exhausted condition of [my]103-mrs. van brandt brain , previously excited by delusions which had lasted uninterruptedly for many hours together . Let the cause be what it might , during the greater part of the voyage [I]103-mrs. van brandt was awake at intervals only . The rest of the time [I]103-mrs. van brandt lay like a weary animal , lost in sleep . When [I]103-mrs. van brandt stepped on [shore]3297-shore at [Rotterdam]60-rotterdam , [my]103-mrs. van brandt first proceeding was to ask [my]103-mrs. van brandt way to [the English Consulate]4195-the english consulate . [I]103-mrs. van brandt had [my]103-mrs. van brandt traveling - bag with [me]103-mrs. van brandt . Difficulties which [I]1993-the englishman had not anticipated occurred in finding [the boat]2461-the boat and in engaging [a crew]4226-a crew . This done , it was next necessary to purchase provisions for the voyage . Thanks to the experience of [[my]1993-the englishman companion]946-my companion , and to the hearty good - will with which [he]946-my companion exerted it , [my]1993-the englishman preparations were completed before night - fall . [I]1993-the englishman was able to set sail for [my]1993-the englishman destination on the next day . [The boat]2461-the boat had the double advantage , in navigating [the Zuyder Zee]17-the zuyder zee , of being large , and of drawing very little water ; [[the captain]851-the captain ’s cabin]855-the captain ’s cabin was at the stern ; and [the two or three men who formed [[his]851-the captain crew]4232-his crew]4231-the two or three men who formed his crew were berthed forward , in the bows . Under these circumstances , [I]1993-the englishman had no reason to complain of want of space ; [the vessel]2622-the vessel measuring between fifty and sixty tons . [I]1993-the englishman had a comfortable bed , a table , and chairs . [The kitchen]2381-the kitchen was well away from [me]1993-the englishman , in the forward part of [the boat]2461-the boat . [The Dutch captain]4242-the dutch captain had been employed , at a former period of [his]4242-the dutch captain life , in [the mercantile navy of [France]30-france]4243-the mercantile navy of france ; and [we]4244-we could communicate , whenever it was necessary or desirable , in the French language . [We]4244-we left [the spires of [Amsterdam]61-amsterdam]4245-the spires of amsterdam behind [us]4244-we , and sailed over [the smooth waters of [the lake]289-the lake]4246-the smooth waters of the lake on [our]4244-we way to [the Zuyder Zee]17-the zuyder zee . The history of [this remarkable sea]4248-this remarkable sea is a romance in itself . In the days when [Rome]34-rome was [mistress of [the world]287-the world]4249-mistress of the world , [it]4248-this remarkable sea had no existence . Where the waves now roll , [vast tracts of forest]4251-vast tracts of forest surrounded [a great inland lake]4252-a great inland lake , with but one river to serve [it]4252-a great inland lake as [an outlet to [the sea]3277-the sea]4253-an outlet to the sea . [The Northern Ocean beyond]4258-the northern ocean beyond burst its way in through the gaps of ruin ; and from that time [the Zuyder Zee]17-the zuyder zee existed as [we]4244-we know it now . Such , briefly told , is the strange story of [the Zuyder Zee]17-the zuyder zee . [The mother]1743-the mother looked at [us]4427-us . With a low cry of pain , [she]4428-the proud , sensitive woman hid [her]4428-the proud , sensitive woman face in [her]4428-the proud , sensitive woman hands . Overwhelmed by the sense of [her]4428-the proud , sensitive woman own degradation , [she]4428-the proud , sensitive woman was even ashamed to let [the man who loved [her]4428-the proud , sensitive woman]4429-the man who loved her see that [she]4428-the proud , sensitive woman was in tears . [I]0-i took [the child]2711-the child off [my]0-i knee . There was a second door in [the sitting - room]1040-the sitting - room , which happened to be left open . It showed [me]0-i a [bed - chamber within]4432-bed - chamber within , and a candle burning on the toilet - table . “[0-i] Go in there and play , ” [I]0-i said . “[0-i] [I]0-i want to talk to [[your]0-i mamma]1750-your mamma . ” [The child]2711-the child pouted : [my]1750-your mamma proposal did not appear to tempt [her]2711-the child . “[1750-your mamma] Give [me]0-i something to play with , ” [she]0-i said . “[1750-your mamma] [I]0-i ’m tired of [my]0-i toys . Let [me]0-i see what [you]0-i have got in [your]0-i pockets . ” [Her]2711-the child busy little hands began to search in [my]0-i coat - pockets . [I]0-i let [her]2711-the child take what [she]2711-the child pleased , and so bribed [her]2711-the child to run away into [the inner room]4434-the inner room . As soon as [she]2711-the child was out of sight , [I]0-i approached [the poor mother]4435-the poor mother and seated [myself]0-i by [her]4435-the poor mother side . “[0-i] Think of it as [I]0-i do , ” [I]0-i said . “[0-i] Now that [he]2006-he has forsaken [you]0-i , [he]2006-he has left [you]0-i free to be [mine]2007-mine . ” [She]4435-the poor mother lifted [her]4435-the poor mother head instantly ; [her]4435-the poor mother eyes flashed through [her]4435-the poor mother tears . “[2006-he] Now that [he]2006-he has forsaken [me]0-i , ” [she]4435-the poor mother answered , “[2006-he] [I]0-i am more unworthy of [you]0-i than ever ! ” “[0-i] Why ? ” [I]0-i asked . “[0-i] Why ! ” [she]4435-the poor mother repeated , passionately . “[0-i] Has [a woman]237-a woman not reached the lowest depths of degradation when [she]237-a woman has lived to be deserted by [a thief]4419-a thief ? ” It was hopeless to attempt to reason with [her]4435-the poor mother in [her]4435-the poor mother present frame of mind . [I]0-i tried to attract [her]4435-the poor mother attention to a less painful subject by referring to the strange succession of events which had brought [me]0-i to [her]4435-the poor mother for the third time . [She]4435-the poor mother stopped [me]0-i impatiently at the outset . “[0-i] It seems useless to say once more what [we]2010-we have said on other occasions , ” [she]4435-the poor mother answered . “[2010-we] [I]0-i understand what has brought [you]0-i [here]586-here . [I]0-i have appeared to [you]0-i again in a vision , just as [I]0-i appeared to [you]0-i twice before . ” “[0-i] No , ” [I]0-i said . “[0-i] Not as [you]0-i appeared to [me]0-i twice before . This time [I]0-i saw [you]0-i with [the child]2711-the child by [your]0-i side . ” That reply roused [her]0-i . [She]0-i started , and looked nervously toward the bed - chamber door . “[0-i] Do n’t speak loud ! ” [she]0-i said . “[0-i] Do n’t let [the child]2711-the child hear [us]2010-we ! [My]0-i dream of [you]0-i this time has left a painful impression on [my]0-i mind . [The child]2711-the child is mixed up in it — and [I]0-i do n’t like that . Then the place in which [I]0-i saw [you]0-i is associated — ” [She]0-i paused , leaving the sentence unfinished . “[0-i] [I]0-i am nervous and wretched to - night , ” [she]0-i resumed ; “[0-i] and [I]0-i do n’t want to speak of it . And yet , [I]0-i should like to know whether [my]0-i dream has misled [me]0-i , or whether [you]0-i really were in [that cottage]2015-that cottage , of [all places in [the world]287-the world]2016-all places in the world ? ” [I]2018-i was at a loss to understand the embarrassment which [she]0-i appeared to feel in putting [her]0-i question . There was nothing very wonderful , to [my]2018-i mind , in the discovery that [she]0-i had been in [Suffolk]6-suffolk , and that [she]0-i was acquainted with [Greenwater Broad]5-greenwater broad . [The lake]289-the lake was known all over [the county]4437-the county as [a favorite resort of picnic parties]4438-a favorite resort of picnic parties ; and [[Dermody]88-dame dermody ’s pretty cottage]4439-dermody ’s pretty cottage used to be [one of the popular attractions of the scene]4440-one of the popular attractions of the scene . What really surprised [me]2018-i was to see , as [I]2018-i now plainly saw , that [she]0-i had some painful association with [[my]2018-i old home]2443-my old home . [I]2018-i decided on answering [her]0-i question in such terms as might encourage [her]0-i to take [me]2018-i into [her]0-i confidence . [The child]2711-the child ran out of the bed - chamber , with a quaintly shaped key in [her]0-i hand . It was one of the things [she]0-i had taken out of [my]2018-i pockets and it belonged to the cabin door on board [the boat]2461-the boat . A sudden fit of curiosity ( the insatiable curiosity of [a child]2312-a child ) had seized [her]0-i on the subject of this key . [She]0-i insisted on knowing what door it locked ; and , when [I]2018-i had satisfied [her]0-i on that point , [she]0-i implored [me]2018-i to take [her]0-i immediately to see [the boat]2461-the boat . This entreaty led naturally to a renewal of the disputed question of going , or not going , to bed . By the time [the little creature]3600-the little creature had left [us]4443-we again , with permission to play for a few minutes longer , the conversation between [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt and [myself]2018-i had taken a new direction . Speaking now of [the child]2711-the child ’s health , [we]4443-we were led naturally to the kindred subject of [the child]2711-the child ’s connection with [[her]2711-the child mother]1190-her mother ’s dream . “[2018-i] [She]2018-i had been ill with fever , ” [Mrs. Van Brandt]103-mrs. van brandt began ; “[2018-i] and [she]2018-i was just getting better again on the day when [I]0-i was left deserted in [this miserable place]2019-this miserable place . Toward evening , [she]2018-i had another attack that frightened [me]0-i dreadfully . [She]2018-i became perfectly insensible — [her]2018-i little limbs were stiff and cold . There is [one doctor here who has not yet abandoned [the town]1544-the town]2020-one doctor here who has not yet abandoned the town . Of course [I]0-i sent for [him]2020-one doctor here who has not yet abandoned the town . [He]2020-one doctor here who has not yet abandoned the town thought [her]2018-i insensibility was caused by a sort of cataleptic seizure . At the same time , [he]2020-one doctor here who has not yet abandoned the town comforted [me]0-i by saying that [she]2018-i was in no immediate danger of death ; and [he]2020-one doctor here who has not yet abandoned the town left [me]0-i certain remedies to be given , if certain symptoms appeared . [I]0-i took [her]2018-i to bed , and held [her]2018-i to [me]0-i , with the idea of keeping [her]2018-i warm . Without believing in mesmerism , it has since struck [me]0-i that [we]2022-we might unconsciously have had some influence over [each other]354-each other , which may explain what followed . Do [you]0-i think it likely ? ” “[0-i] Quite likely . At the same time , the mesmeric theory ( if [you]0-i could believe in it ) would carry the explanation further still . Mesmerism would assert , not only that [you]0-i and [the child]2711-the child influenced [each other]354-each other , but that — in spite of the distance — [you]0-i both influenced [me]0-i . And in that way , mesmerism would account for [my]0-i vision as the necessary result of a highly developed sympathy between [us]2022-we . Tell [me]0-i , did [you]0-i fall asleep with [the child]2711-the child in [your]0-i arms ? ” “[0-i] Yes . [I]0-i was completely worn out ; and [I]0-i fell asleep , in spite of [my]0-i resolution to watch through the night . In [my]0-i forlorn situation , forsaken in [a strange place]2027-a strange place , [I]0-i dreamed of [you]0-i again , and [I]0-i appealed to [you]0-i again as [[my]0-i one protector and [friend]2715-friend]2028-my one protector and friend . All through the night there was no change in [her]2711-the child . [She]2711-the child only recovered [her]2711-the child senses at noon the next day . Why do [you]0-i start ? What have [I]0-i said that surprises [you]0-i ? ” There was good reason for [my]2711-the child feeling startled , and showing it . [She]2711-the child said : ‘ [He]2033-he is coming to see [us]2034-us , [mamma]1997-mamma ; and [I]0-i have been showing [him]2033-he the way . ’ [I]0-i asked [her]2711-the child where [she]2711-the child had seen [you]0-i .
